article.title: Keystone Pipeline
article.text:
{{Infobox pipeline |name = Keystone Pipeline System
{{small|(partly operational and proposed)}} |map = Keystone-pipeline-route.png |map_caption = Keystone Pipeline Route |country = [[Canada]]
[[United States]] |type = [[Crude oil]] |owner = [[TransCanada Corporation|TransCanada]] |partners = |operator = |technical_service_provider = |website = {{URL|http://www.keystone-xl.com/|keystone-xl.com}} }} The '''Keystone Pipeline System''' is an [[oil pipeline]] system in Canada and the United States, commissioned in 2010 and now owned solely by [[TransCanada Corporation]].{{cite web |url=http://www.transcanada.com/liquids-pipelines-projects.html |title=Keystone Pipeline System |publisher=TransCanada |accessdate=2012-07-19}} It runs from the [[Western Canadian Sedimentary Basin]] in [[Alberta]] to refineries in [[Illinois]] and [[Texas]], and also to oil [[Oil terminal|tank farms]] and an oil pipeline distribution center in [[Cushing, Oklahoma]]. The pipeline came to a greater prominence of attention when a planned fourth phase, Keystone XL, attracting growing environmental protest, became a symbol of the battle over [[Attribution of recent climate change|climate change and fossil fuels]], and in 2015 was temporarily delayed by then [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]]. On January 24, 2017, President [[Donald Trump]] [[List of executive actions by Donald Trump|took action]] intended to permit the pipeline's completion. In November 2017, 210,000 gallons of oil leaked from the pipeline in South Dakota. Three phases of the project are in operation. They are: * The Keystone Pipeline (Phase I), delivering oil from [[Hardisty]], [[Alberta]], over {{convert|3456|km}} to the junction at [[Steele City, Nebraska]], and on to [[Wood River Refinery]] in [[Roxana, Illinois]], and Patoka Oil Terminal Hub (tank farm) north of [[Patoka, Illinois]], completed in June 2010. * The Keystone-Cushing extension (Phase II), running {{convert|468|km}} from Steele City to storage and distribution facilities (tank farm) at [[Cushing, Oklahoma]], completed in February 2011. * The Gulf Coast Extension (Phase III), running {{convert|784|km}} from Cushing to refineries at [[Port Arthur, Texas]] was completed in January 2014, and a lateral pipeline to refineries at [[Houston, Texas]] and a terminal will be completed mid-2016, going online the following year. The proposed Keystone XL (sometimes abbreviated KXL, with XL standing for "export limited"{{cite web|last1=Rapier|first1=Robert|title=There's No Stopping the Oil Sands Train|url=https://www.investingdaily.com/18811/theres-no-stopping-the-oil-sands-train/|accessdate=24 January 2017|date=19 November 2013}}) Pipeline (Phase IV) would essentially duplicate (though along a shorter route and with a larger-diameter pipe) the Phase I pipeline between Hardisty, Alberta, and Steele City, Nebraska.{{cite web |url=http://keystone-xl.com/about/the-project/ |title=:Keystone XL Pipeline: About the project |publisher=TransCanada |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130426005127/http://keystone-xl.com/about/the-project/ |archivedate=2013-04-26 |df= }} It would run through [[Baker, Montana]], where American-produced [[light crude oil]] from the [[Williston Basin]] ([[Bakken formation]]) of [[Montana]] and [[North Dakota]] would be added{{cite report|author=United States Department of State Bureau of Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs|publisher=United States Department of State|title=Draft Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement for the KEYSTONE XL PROJECT Applicant for Presidential Permit: TransCanada Keystone Pipeline, LP (SEIS)|date=2013-03-01|accessdate=2013-03-17|url=http://keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/documents/organization/205719.pdf|format=PDF}} to the Keystone's throughput of [[synthetic crude oil]] (syncrude) and [[dilbit|diluted bitumen (dilbit)]] from the [[oil sands]] of Canada. After more than six years of review, President Barack Obama announced on November 6, 2015, his administration's rejection of the fourth phase. On January 24, 2017, President Trump signed [[presidential memorandum|presidential memoranda]] to revive both the Keystone XL and [[Dakota Access Pipeline|Dakota Access]] pipelines. The memorandum is designed to expedite the environmental review process.{{cite news |last=Mufson |first=Steven |date=January 24, 2017 |title= Trump seeks to revive Dakota Access, Keystone XL oil pipelines|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2017/01/24/trump-gives-green-light-to-dakota-access-keystone-xl-oil-pipelines/ |newspaper=Washington Post |location=Washington, DC |access-date=January 24, 2017}} The first two phases have the capacity to deliver up to {{convert|590000|oilbbl/d}} of oil into the Midwest refineries.{{cite web|title=Keystone Pipeline |url=http://www.transcanada.com/100.html |accessdate=2013-03-17 |publisher=[[TransCanada Corporation]] |location=Calgary, Alberta, Canada |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116010600/http://transcanada.com/100.html |archivedate=January 16, 2013 }} Phase III has capacity to deliver up to {{convert|700000|oilbbl/d}} to the Texas refineries. By comparison, U.S. oil production averaged {{convert|9400000|oilbbl/d}} in first-half 2015, with gross exports of {{convert|500000|oilbbl/d}} through July 2015.{{cite web|title=Short-Term Energy and Winter Fuels Outlook|url=http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/us_oil.cfm|accessdate=8 November 2015|publisher=[[Energy Information Administration|US Energy Information Administration]]}} ==Description== The Keystone Pipeline system consists of the operational Phase I, Phase II, and Phase III, the Gulf Coast Pipeline Project. A fourth, proposed pipeline expansion segment Phase IV, Keystone XL, failed to receive necessary permits from the United States federal government in 2015. Construction of Phase III, from Cushing, Oklahoma, to Nederland, Texas, in the Gulf Coast area, began in August 2012 as an independent economic utility.It was presented to the United States State Department as an independent economic utility in February 2012, sidestepping the requirement for a Presidential Permit because it does not cross an international border (United States Department of State SEIS March 1, 2013 p. ES1).{{cite web |title=Gulf Coast Pipeline Project |url=http://www.transcanada.com/gulf-coast-pipeline-project.html |accessdate=March 17, 2013 |publisher=TransCanada Corporation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130121135703/http://transcanada.com/gulf-coast-pipeline-project.html |archivedate=January 21, 2013 |df= }} Phase III was opened on 22 January 2014, completing the pipeline path from Hardisty, Alberta to Nederland, Texas.{{cite news | url = http://www.spacedaily.com/reports/US_leg_of_controversial_Canadian_oil_pipeline_opens_999.html | title = US leg of controversial Canadian oil pipeline opens | work = Space Daily | date = 2014-01-22 | accessdate = 2014-01-24}} The Keystone XL Pipeline Project (Phase IV) revised proposal in 2012 consists of a new {{convert|36|in|adj=on}} pipeline from Hardisty, Alberta, through Montana and South Dakota to Steele City, Nebraska, to "transport of up to {{convert|830000|oilbbl/d}} of crude oil from the Western Canadian Sedimentary Basin in Alberta, Canada, and from the Williston Basin (Bakken) region in Montana and North Dakota, primarily to refineries in the Gulf Coast area." The Keystone XL pipeline segments were intended to allow American crude oil to enter the XL pipelines at [[Baker, Montana]], on their way to the storage and distribution facilities at [[Cushing, Oklahoma]]. Cushing is a major crude oil marketing/refining and pipeline hub.{{Cite news|title=Keystone XL Pipeline |date=28 February 2012 |publisher=The New York Times |url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/k/keystone_pipeline/index.html |first1=John M. |last1=Broder |first2=Clifford |last2=Krauss}} Operating since 2010, the original Keystone Pipeline System is a {{convert|3461|km|adj=on}} pipeline delivering Canadian crude oil to U.S. Midwest markets and Cushing, Oklahoma. In Canada, the first phase of Keystone involved the conversion of approximately {{convert|864|km}} of existing {{convert|36|in|adj=on}} natural gas pipeline in Saskatchewan and Manitoba to crude oil pipeline service. It also included approximately {{convert|373|km}} of new {{convert|30|in|adj=on}} diameter pipeline, 16 pump stations and the Keystone Hardisty Terminal. The U.S. portion of the Keystone Pipeline included {{convert|1744|km}} of new, {{convert|30|in|adj=on}} diameter pipeline in North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Missouri and Illinois. The pipeline has a minimum ground cover of {{convert|4|ft}}. It also involved construction of 23 pump stations and delivery facilities at Wood River and Patoka, Illinois. In 2011, the second phase of Keystone included a {{convert|480|km|0|adj=on}} extension from Steele City, Nebraska, to Cushing, Oklahoma, and 11 new pump stations to increase the capacity of the pipeline from {{convert|435000|to|591000|oilbbl/d|lk=in}}.{{cite news | url = http://abarrelfull.wikidot.com/keystone-pipeline | title = Keystone Pipeline | newspaper = A Barrel Full | date = 2012-03-02 | accessdate = 2012-07-19}} Additional phases (III, completed in 2014, and IV, rejected in 2015) have been in construction or discussion since 2011. If completed, the Keystone XL would have added {{convert|510000|oilbbl/d}} increasing the total capacity up to {{convert|1.1|Moilbbl/d}}. The original Keystone Pipeline cost US$5.2 billion with the Keystone XL expansion slated to cost approximately US$7 billion. The Keystone XL had been expected to be completed by 2012–2013, however construction was ultimately overtaken by events. ===Ownership=== While the project was originally developed as a partnership between [[TransCanada Corporation]] and [[ConocoPhillips]], TransCanada is now the sole owner of the Keystone Pipeline System, as TransCanada received regulatory approval on August 12, 2009 to purchase ConocoPhillips' interest.{{cite web |title= Keystone Pipeline System |url= http://www.transcanada.com/keystone/ |publisher= TransCanada Corporation |accessdate=8 September 2009}} Certain parties who have agreed to make volume commitments to the Keystone expansion have the option to acquire up to a combined 15% equity ownership.{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=11890 | title = TransCanada, ConocoPhillips To Expand Keystone To Gulf Coast | work = TransCanada | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2008-07-16 | accessdate = 2008-07-18}} One such company is [[Valero Energy Corporation]].{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=11910 | title = Valero: Prospective Keystone Shipper | work = Valero Energy | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2008-07-16 | accessdate = 2008-07-18}} ==Route== ===Phase 1 (complete)=== {{Infobox pipeline |name = Keystone Pipeline
(Phase 1) (Complete) |type = [[Crude oil]] |coordinates = |start = [[Hardisty, Alberta]] |through = [[Regina, Saskatchewan]]
[[Steele City, Nebraska]] |finish = [[Wood River, Illinois]]
[[Patoka, Illinois]] (end) |contractors = |construction = Q2 2008 |est = June 2010 |decom = |length_km = 3456 |discharge = |capacity = |discharge_bbl_d = 0.86 |diameter_in = 30 |pumping_stations_no = 39 |pumping_stations = }} This {{convert|3456|km|mi|adj=mid|-long}} pipeline runs from [[Hardisty, Alberta]], to the junction at [[Steele City, Nebraska]], and on to the [[Wood River Refinery]] in [[Roxana, Illinois]], and Patoka Oil Terminal Hub (tank farm) north of [[Patoka, Illinois]]. {{cite news |url = http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article150750.ece |title = Canada-US link gets green light |newspaper = [[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] |publisher = NHST Media Group |date = 2008-03-14 |accessdate = 2008-03-14 |id = {{subscription required}}}} The Canadian section involves approximately {{convert|864|km}} of pipeline converted from the Canadian Mainline natural gas pipeline and {{convert|373|km}} of new pipeline, pump stations and terminal facilities at Hardisty, Alberta.{{cite news |url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=6776 |title = TransCanada: Keystone Construction to Begin in Spring |work = TransCanada Corporation |publisher = Downstream Today |date = 2007-10-30 |accessdate = 2008-07-18}} The United States section is {{convert|2219|km}} long. It runs through [[Buchanan County, Missouri|Buchanan]], [[Clinton County, Missouri|Clinton]], [[Caldwell County, Missouri|Caldwell]], [[Montgomery County, Missouri|Montgomery]], [[Lincoln County, Missouri|Lincoln]] and [[St. Charles County, Missouri|St. Charles]] counties in [[Missouri]], and [[Nemaha County, Kansas|Nemaha]], [[Brown County, Kansas|Brown]] and [[Doniphan County, Kansas|Doniphan]] counties in [[Kansas]] before entering [[Madison County, Illinois|Madison]] County, Illinois. Phase 1 went online in June 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.transcanada.com/5407.html|title=Keystone Pipeline Starts Deliveries to U.S. Midwest|publisher=}} [[File:Pipes for keystone pipeline in 2009.jpg|thumb|left|Keystone {{convert|30|in|mm|abbr=on}} pipeline (phase 1) near [[Swanton, Nebraska]] (2009)]] {{Clear}} ===Phase 2 (complete)=== {{Infobox pipeline |name = Keystone-Cushing Project
(Phase 2) (Complete) |type = [[Crude oil]] |coordinates = |start = {{Nowrap|[[Steele City, Nebraska]]}} |finish = {{Nowrap|[[Cushing, Oklahoma]]}} |contractors = [[WorleyParsons]] |construction = 2010 |est = February 2011 |decom = |length_km = 468 |discharge = |discharge_bbl_d = |diameter_in = 36 |pumping_stations_no = 4 |pumping_stations = }} The '''Keystone-Cushing''' pipeline phase connected the Keystone pipeline (phase 1) in [[Steele City, Nebraska]], south through Kansas to the oil hub and tank farm in [[Cushing, Oklahoma]], a distance of {{convert|468|km|mi|adj=mid|-long}}. It was constructed in 2010 and went online in February 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.transcanada.com/5641.html|title=Keystone’s Cushing Extension Begins Deliveries to Oklahoma|publisher=}} [[File:Truck Hauling 36-inch Pipe To Build Keystone XL Pipeline.jpg|thumb|left|Truck hauling {{convert|36|in|mm|abbr=on}} pipe to build Keystone-Cushing pipeline (phase 2) southeast of [[Peabody, Kansas]] (2010)]] {{Clear}} ===Phase 3a (complete)=== {{Infobox pipeline |name = Cushing Marketlink Project
(Phase 3a) (Complete) |type = [[Crude oil]] |coordinates = |start = [[Cushing, Oklahoma]] |through = [[Liberty County, Texas]] |finish = [[Nederland, Texas]] |contractors = [[WorleyParsons]] |construction = Summer 2012 |est = January 2014 |decom = |length_km = 784 |discharge_bbl_d = 0.7 |diameter_in = 36 |pumping_stations_no = |pumping_stations = }} The '''Cushing MarketLink''' pipeline phase started at [[Cushing, Oklahoma]], where American-produced oil is added to the pipeline, then runs south {{convert|435|mi|km}} to a delivery point near terminals in [[Nederland, Texas]], to serve refineries in the [[Port Arthur, Texas]], area. Keystone started pumping oil through this section in January 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.transcanada.com/6074.html|title=TransCanada Receives Final Key Gulf Coast Project Permit Construction Set to Begin this Summer|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.transcanada.com/news-releases-article.html?id=1800856|title=Gulf Coast Project Begins Delivering Crude Oil to Nederland, Texas|publisher=}}{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/01/22/transcanada-begins-keystone-pipeline-in-texas/ | work=Fox News | title=TransCanada begins Keystone pipeline in Texas. | date=2014-01-22}} Oil producers in the U.S. pushed for this phase so the glut of oil can be distributed out of the large oil tank farms and distribution center in Cushing. {{Clear}} ===Phase 3b (complete)=== {{Infobox pipeline |name = Houston Lateral Project
(Phase 3b)
(Complete) |type = [[Crude oil]] |coordinates = |start = [[Liberty County, Texas]] |finish = [[Houston, Texas]] |contractors = [[WorleyParsons]] |construction = 2013 |est = 2016, online 2017 |decom = |length_km = 76 |discharge = |discharge_bbl_d = |diameter_in = |pumping_stations_no = |pumping_stations = }} The '''Houston Lateral''' pipeline phase is a {{convert|47|mi|km|adj=on}} pipeline to transport crude oil from the pipeline in [[Liberty County, Texas]], to refineries and terminal in the [[Houston]] area. This phase was constructed 2013 to 2016 and went online in 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.transcanada.com/en/operations/oil-and-liquids/|title=operations|publisher=transcanada}} {{Clear}} === {{anchor|Phase 4 (cancelled)}}Phase 4 === {{Infobox pipeline |name = Keystone XL Pipeline
(Phase 4){{cite news|last1=Koring|first1=Paul|title=Obama rejects TransCanada's Keystone XL Pipeline|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/energy-and-resources/obama-to-reject-transcanadas-keystone-xl-pipeline-source-says/article27144973/|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=The Globe and Mail|date=6 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120214904/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/energy-and-resources/obama-to-reject-transcanadas-keystone-xl-pipeline-source-says/article27144973/|archivedate=20 January 2016|df=}} |type = [[Crude oil]] |coordinates = |start = [[Hardisty, Alberta]] |through = [[Baker, Montana]] |finish = [[Steele City, Nebraska]] |contractors = [[WorleyParsons]] |construction = Unknown |expected = 2019{{cite web|last1=Monga|first1=Vipal|title=Keystone XL Pipeline Obtains Enough Shipper Commitments to Proceed|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/keystone-xl-pipeline-obtains-enough-shipper-commitments-to-proceed-1516298281|website=Wall Street Journal|publisher=News Corp|accessdate=19 January 2018}} |est = |decom = |length_km = 1897 |discharge = |discharge_bbl_d = |diameter_in = 36 |pumping_stations_no = |pumping_stations = }} The proposed '''Keystone XL''' pipeline starts from the same area in [[Alberta, Canada]], as the Phase 1 pipeline. The Canadian section would consist of {{convert|526|km}} of new pipeline. It would enter the United States at [[Morgan, Montana]], and travel through [[Baker, Montana]], where American-produced oil would be added to the pipeline; then it would travel through South Dakota and Nebraska, where it would join the existing Keystone pipelines at [[Steele City, Nebraska]]. This phase has generated the greatest controversy because of its routing over the [[Sandhills (Nebraska)|Sandhills]] in Nebraska. {{cite news|url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/the-politics-of-pipe-keystones-troubled-route/article2282805/singlepage/#articlecontent |title = The politics of pipe: Keystone's troubled route |first = Nathan | last = VanderKlippe |newspaper = [[The Globe and Mail]] |date = 2011-12-24 |accessdate = 2012-12-09 |location=Toronto}} On 6 November 2015, the project of Keystone XL was rejected by the [[Obama administration]] after more than six years of review and initial approval by the Obama State Department.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2015/11/06/obama-reject-keystone-pipeline/75293270/|title=Obama administration rejects Keystone pipeline|publisher=}} Leading up to this, financial commitment towards completion of the pipeline was weakened by a number of technological factors as well. Recent innovations in fracking had increased domestic production of oil and, according to the EIA, reduced annual demand of oil from foreign countries to an all-time low since 1985. Shifts to Gasoline fuel for cargo vehicles, new technologies promoting fuel efficiency, and export restrictions that forced the price of oil to decrease also played a part.{{Cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/business/the_juice/2015/11/obama_didn_t_kill_the_keystone_xl_pipeline_innovation_did.html|title=Obama Didn’t Kill Keystone XL|last=Gross|first=Daniel|date=2015-11-06|work=Slate|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-US|issn=1091-2339}} In the wake of Obama's decision, aides to then President Elect [[Donald Trump]] were reportedly looking for the easiest way(s) to countermand it.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-11-23/trump-aides-eye-reviving-keystone-by-rescinding-lbj-s-order|title=Trump Aides Eye Reviving Keystone by Rescinding LBJ’s Order|date=23 November 2016|publisher=|via=www.bloomberg.com}} On January 18, 2018 TransCanada announced they had secured commitments to ship 500,000 barrels per day for 20 years. They believe construction could begin in 2019. ==History== ===Preliminary stage=== [[TransCanada Corporation]] proposed the project on February 9, 2005.{{cite web | url=http://www.transcanada.com/3174.html | title =TransCanada Proposes Keystone Oil Pipeline Project | author =transcanada.com | publisher =''[[TransCanada Corporation]]'' | date =February 9, 2005}} In October 2007, the [[Communications, Energy and Paperworkers Union of Canada]] asked the Canadian federal government to block regulatory approvals for the pipeline, with union president Dave Coles stating "the Keystone pipeline will exclusively serve US markets, create a permanent employment for very few Canadians, reduce our energy security, and hinder investment and job creation in the Canadian energy sector."{{cite news | title= Union calls on Ottawa to block Keystone | url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/1036020/union-calls-on-ottawa-to-block-keystone | date= 2007-10-24 | newspaper = [[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] | publisher = NHST Media Group | accessdate= 2010-07-22 | url-access=subscription}} The [[National Energy Board]] of Canada approved the construction of the Canadian section of the pipeline, including converting a portion of TransCanada's Canadian Mainline gas pipeline to crude oil pipeline, on September 21, 2007.{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=6118 | title = TransCanada: Keystone Construction to Start Early Next Year | work = TransCanada Corporation | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2007-09-21 | accessdate = 2008-07-18}} On March 17, 2008, the [[United States Department of State]] issued a Presidential Permit authorizing the construction, maintenance and operation of facilities at the United States and Canada border.{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=9385 | title = State Dept. Grants Keystone Permit; Work To Start In Q2 | work = TransCanada Corporation | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2008-03-17 | accessdate = 2008-07-18}} On January 22, 2008, [[ConocoPhillips]] acquired a 50% stake in the project.{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=8220 | title = ConocoPhillips Acquires 50% Stake in Keystone | work = [[ConocoPhillips]] | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2008-01-22 | accessdate = 2008-07-18}} On June 17, 2009, TransCanada agreed that they would buy out ConocoPhillips' share in the project and revert to being the sole owner. It took TransCanada more than two years to acquire all the necessary state and federal permits for the pipeline. Construction took another two years.{{cite news | url = http://www.edmontonjournal.com/business/TransCanada+Keystone+pipeline+ready+flow+market+there/3126407/story.html | title = TransCanada's Keystone pipeline ready for flow, but is the market there? | newspaper = St. Louis Post-Dispatch | first = Phillip | last = O'Connor | date = 2010-06-08 | accessdate = 2011-02-23}} The pipeline, from [[Hardisty, Alberta]], Canada, to [[Patoka, Illinois]], United States, became operational in June 2010.{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=22938 | title = Oil Flows Through Keystone | newspaper = St. Joseph News-Press | publisher = Downstream Today | first = Ken | last = Newton | date = 2010-06-09 | accessdate = 2010-08-01}} On June 3, 2011, [[PHMSA]] issued TransCanada a Corrective Action Order (CAO), for Keystone's May 2011 leaks.https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320115006H/320115006H_Amended%20CAO_06282011_text.pdf On April 9, 2016, PHMSA issued a CAO to TransCanada, for a 16,800 gallon leak in [[Hutchinson County, South Dakota]], on April 2.https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320165003H/320165003H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_04092016.pdf The pipeline restarted at a reduced operating pressure on April 10 after the U.S. regulator approved the companies corrective actions and plan.De Souza, Mike. (10 April 2016). "TransCanada restarts Keystone pipeline after repairing leak". [https://www.nationalobserver.com/2016/04/10/news/transcanada-restarts-keystone-pipeline-after-repairing-leak National Observer website] Retrieved 18 November 2017. A 9,700 barrel (407,400 gallons) leak occurred in [[Marshall County, South Dakota]] in November 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/keystone-pipeline-leak-was-twice-big-previously-thought-180968722/|title=Keystone Pipeline Leak Was Twice as Big as Previously Thought|first=Brigit|last=Katz|work=Smithsonian|date=April 9, 2018}} This leak occurred early in the morning on November 16, 2017 near [[Amherst, South Dakota]] and was contained shortly after detection 35 miles south of the Ludden pump station.{{cite news|last1=Mufson|first1=Steven|last2=Mooney|first2=Chris|date=November 17, 2017|title=Keystone pipeline spills 210,000 gallons of oil on eve of permitting decision for TransCanada|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2017/11/16/keystone-pipeline-spills-210000-gallons-of-oil-on-eve-of-key-permitting-decision/|work=The Washington Post}} ===Keystone XL=== [[File:Presidential Memorandum Regarding Construction of the Keystone XL Pipeline.pdf|thumb|Presidential Memorandum Regarding Construction of the Keystone XL Pipeline (2017)]] The Keystone XL extension was proposed in 2008.{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=11336 | title = TransCanada Proposes Second Oil Pipeline | newspaper = Lincoln Journal-Star | publisher = Downstream Today | first = Art | last = Hovey | date = 2008-06-12 | accessdate = 2008-07-18}} The application was filed in September 2008 and the National Energy Board of Canada started hearings in September 2009.{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=16359 | title = NEB Sets Keystone XL Hearing | work = National Energy Board | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2009-05-13 | accessdate = 2010-08-01}} On March 11, 2010, the Canadian National Energy Board approved the project.{{cite news |title=Keystone XL Pipeline |date=28 February 2012 |newspaper = [[The New York Times]] |url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/k/keystone_pipeline/index.html |accessdate=March 26, 2012 |first1=John M. |last1=Broder |first2=Clifford |last2=Krauss}}{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=21604 | title = NEB Okays Keystone XL | work = National Energy Board | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2010-03-11 | accessdate = 2010-08-01}}{{cite report |url= http://www.ilr.cornell.edu/globallaborinstitute/research/upload/GLI_KeystoneXL_Reportpdf.pdf |title= Pipe dreams? Jobs Gained, Jobs Lost by the Construction of Keystone XL |publisher= [[Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations|ILR School Global Labor Institute]] |format = PDF |date=September 2011 |accessdate=2011-10-12}} The [[South Dakota Public Utilities Commission]] granted a permit to proceed on February 19, 2010.{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=21202 | title = Keystone XL Clears Hurdle In South Dakota | work = South Dakota Public Utilities Commission | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2010-02-19 | accessdate = 2010-08-01}} On July 21, 2010, the [[Environmental Protection Agency]] said the draft environmental impact study for Keystone XL was inadequate and should be revised, indicating that the State Department's original report was "unduly narrow" because it did not fully look at oil spill response plans, safety issues and [[greenhouse gas]] concerns.{{cite news | title= EPA: Keystone XL impact statement needs revising | url= http://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory?id=11219127 | date= 2010-07-21 | first = Maria | last = Sudekum Fisher | agency = [[Associated Press]] | accessdate = 2011-04-27}}{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=23434 | title = EPA Calls for Further Study of Keystone XL | agency = [[Dow Jones Newswires]] | first = Edward | last = Welsch | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2010-07-21 | accessdate = 2010-08-01}}{{cite news | url = http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2011/02/13/108558/canada-pipeline-deal-too-costly.html | title = Oil pipeline from Canada stirring anger in U.S. Great Plains | newspaper = [[McClatchy Newspapers]] | first1 = David | last1 = Goldstein | agency = McClatchy Washington Bureau | date = 2011-02-13 | accessdate = 2011-02-15}} The final environmental impact report was released on August 26, 2011. It stated that the pipeline would pose "no significant impacts" to most resources if environmental protection measures are followed, but it would present "significant adverse effects to certain cultural resources".{{cite news | url = http://downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=27703 | title = Keystone Poses 'No Significant Impacts' to Most Resources Along Path – US | agency = [[Dow Jones Newswires]] | publisher = Downstream Today | first1 = Tennille | last1 = Tracy | first2 = Edward | last2 = Welsch | date = 2011-08-26 | accessdate = 2011-08-27}} In September 2011, [[Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations|Cornell ILR Global Labor Institute]] released the results of the GLI Keystone XL Report, which evaluated the pipeline's impact on employment, the environment, [[energy independence]], the economy, and other critical areas. On November 10, 2011, the Department of State postponed a final decision due to necessity "to seek additional information regarding potential alternative routes around the Sandhills in [[Nebraska]] to inform the determination regarding whether issuing a permit for the proposed Keystone XL pipeline is in the [[national interest]]".{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/06/column-kemp-oil-keystone-idINL6E8K6D5920120906 | title = Keystone modifications call Obama's bluff | first = John | last = Kemp | agency = Reuters | date = 2012-09-06 | accessdate = 2012-10-06}} In its response, TransCanada pointed out fourteen different routes for Keystone XL were being studied, eight that impacted Nebraska. They included one potential alternative route in Nebraska that would have avoided the entire Sandhills region and [[Ogallala Aquifer]] and six alternatives that would have reduced pipeline mileage crossing the Sandhills or the aquifer.{{cite press release | url = http://www.transcanada.com/5893.html | title = TransCanada to Work with Department of State on New Keystone XL Route Options | publisher = TransCanada | date = 2011-11-10 | accessdate = 2011-11-26}}{{cite press release | url = http://www.transcanada.com/5896.html | title = Media Advisory – State of Nebraska to Play Major Role in Defining New Keystone XL Route Away From the Sandhills | publisher = TransCanada | date = 2011-11-14 | accessdate = 2011-11-26}} On November 22, 2011, the Nebraska unicameral legislature passed unanimously two bills with the governor's signature that enacted a compromise agreed upon with the pipeline builder to move the route, and approved up to US$2 million in state funding for an environmental study.{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/22/us-oil-pipeline-nebraska-idUSTRE7AL1M120111122 | title = Nebraska governor signs bills to reroute Keystone pipeline | first = Michael | last = Avok | agency = Reuters | date = 2011-11-22 | accessdate = 2011-11-30}} On November 30, 2011, a group of Republican senators introduced legislation aimed at forcing the Obama administration to make a decision within 60 days.{{cite news| url = http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700202839/GOP-bill-would-force-action-on-Canada-oil-pipeline.html| title = GOP bill would force action on Canada oil pipeline| first = Matthew | last = Daly| agency = [[Associated Press]]| newspaper = [[Deseret News]]| date = 2011-11-30| accessdate = 2012-01-19}} In December 2011, Congress passed a bill giving the Obama Administration a 60-day deadline to make a decision on the application to build the Keystone XL Pipeline.{{cite news |title=Obama denies Keystone XL pipeline permit |first =Brian | last = Montopoli |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-57361324-503544/obama-denies-keystone-xl-pipeline-permit/?tag=stack |work=CBS News |date=January 18, 2012 |accessdate=January 20, 2012}} In January 2012, Obama rejected the application stating that the deadline for the decision had "prevented a full assessment of the pipeline's impact".{{cite news |title=Keystone XL pipeline: Obama rejects controversial project |first =Suzanne | last = Goldenberg |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/jan/18/obama-administration-rejects-keystone-xl-pipeline?newsfeed=true |newspaper = [[The Guardian]] |date=January 18, 2012 |accessdate= January 20, 2012 |location=London}} On September 5, 2012, TransCanada submitted an environmental report on the new route in Nebraska, which the company says is "based on extensive feedback from Nebraskans, and reflects our shared desire to minimize the disturbance of land and sensitive resources in the state".{{cite news| url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/05/pipeline-keystone-route-idUSL2E8K56YB20120905 | title =TransCanada proposes new Keystone XL route in Nebraska | agency = Reuters | date = 2012-09-05 | accessdate = 2012-10-06}} In March 2012, Obama endorsed the building of the southern segment (Gulf Coast Extension or Phase III) that begins in Cushing, Oklahoma. The President said in Cushing, Oklahoma, on March 22, "Today, I'm directing my administration to cut through the red tape, break through the bureaucratic hurdles, and make this project a priority, to go ahead and get it done."{{cite press release| url = http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2012/03/22/remarks-president-american-made-energy| title = Remarks of the President| publisher = The White House| date = 2012-03-22| accessdate = 2013-03-04}} On September 27, 2012, protesters began [[tree sitting]] in the path of the Keystone pipeline near [[Winnsboro, Texas]]. Eight people stood on tree platforms just ahead of where crews were cutting down trees to make way for the pipeline.{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/business/article/Protesters-in-Texas-climb-trees-to-block-pipeline-3891002.php |title=Protesters in Texas climb trees to block pipeline work |publisher=Houston Chronicle |date=September 25, 2012}} On October 4, 2012, actress and activist [[Daryl Hannah]] and 78-year-old Texas landowner Eleanor Fairchild were arrested for criminal trespassing and other charges after they were accused of standing in front of TransCanada pipeline construction equipment on Fairchild's farm in Winnsboro, a town about 100 miles east of Dallas.{{cite web|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/nation/15598994-418/daryl-hannah-freed-following-arrest-in-pipeline-protest.html |title=Daryl Hannah freed following arrest in pipeline protest |publisher=Chicago Sun-Times |date=Oct 6, 2012}} Ms. Fairchild had owned the land since 1983 and refused to sign any agreements with TransCanada. Her land was seized by eminent domain. In its supplemental environmental impact statement (SEIS) released in March 2013, the U.S. Department of State [[Bureau of Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs]] described changes to the original proposals including the shortening of the pipeline to {{convert|875|mi}}; its avoidance of "crossing the NDEQ-identified Sandhills Region" and "reduction of the length of pipeline crossing the Northern High Plains Aquifer system, which includes the Ogallala formation"; and stated "there would be no significant impacts to most resources along the proposed Project route." In response to a Freedom of Information Act request for route information, the Department of State revealed on June 24, 2013, that "Neither Cardno ENTRIX nor TransCanada ever submitted [[Geographic information system|GIS]] information to the Department of State, nor was either corporation required to do so."{{cite web|last=Bachand|first=Thomas|title=Final Response to FOIA: "No GIS Data"|url=http://keystone.steamingmules.com/foia-response-dos-no-digital-data/|work=Keystone Mapping Project|accessdate=26 February 2014}} In response to the Department of State's report, which recommended neither acceptance nor rejection, an editor of ''[[The New York Times]]'' recommended that Obama should reject the project, which "even by the State Department's most cautious calculations — can only add to the [climate change] problem."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/11/opinion/when-to-say-no-to-the-keystone-xl.html?smid=pl-share|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 10, 2013|author=Editorial|title=When to Say No }}The Alberta government placed a $30,000 ad entitled "Keystone XL: The Choice of Reason" in ''The New York Times'' to counter the editorial (CBC March 17, 2013). On March 21, [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] revealed that key personnel employed by [http://www.erm.com/ Environment Resources Management] (ERM), the consulting firm responsible for generating most of the SEIS, had previously performed contract work for TransCanada corporation. In addition, When the State Department released the original proposal ERM had submitted to secure the SEIS contract, portions of the work histories of key personnel were redacted.{{cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2013/03/keystone-xl-contractor-ties-transcanada-state-department|title=Exclusive: State Dept. Hid Contractor's Ties to Keystone XL Pipeline Company|work=Mother Jones}} In April 2013, the [[EPA]] challenged the U.S. State Department report's conclusion that the pipeline would not result in greater oil sand production, noting that "while informative, [it] is not based on an updated energy-economic modeling effort".{{Citation|author=Cynthia Giles|title=Letter from C. Giles (EPA) to J. Fernandez & K.-A. Jones (SD)|publisher=.S. Environmental Protection Agency|pages=1–7|date=April 22, 2013|accessdate=September 14, 2013|url=http://epa.gov/compliance/nepa/keystone-xl-project-epa-comment-letter-20130056.pdf|format=PDF }}{{cite news|title=Oil, money and politics; EPA snags Keystone XL pipeline|publisher=CNN|date=April 23, 2013|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/04/23/politics/keystone-xl-pipeline/index.html|accessdate=September 14, 2013}} Overall, the EPA rated the SEIS with their category "EO-2" (EO for "environmental objections" and 2 for "insufficient information").Cynthia Jones (U.S. EPA), [http://www.epa.gov/compliance/nepa/keystone-xl-project-epa-comment-letter-20130056.pdf letter to U.S. Dept. of State concerning Keystone XL pipeline], 22 Apr, 2013. In May 2013 Republicans in the House of Representatives defended the Northern Route Approval Act, which would allow for congressional approval of the pipeline, on the grounds that the pipeline created jobs and energy independence. If enacted the Northern Route Approval Act would waive the requirement for permits for a foreign company and bypass the need for President Obama's approval, and the debate in the Democrat-controlled U.S. Senate, concerned about serious environmental risks, that could result in the rejection of the pipeline.{{cite news|title=Republicans aim to take Keystone XL decision out of Obama's hands |first=Lee-Anne |last=Goodman |publisher=The Canadian Press |date=22 May 2013 |url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/business/Republicans+take+Keystone+decision+Obama+hands/8420625/story.html#ixzz2U8R6yL8f }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On January 22, 2014, the Gulf Coast Extension (phase III) was opened. On January 9, 2015, the U.S. House voted 266–153 in favor of the pipeline. On the same day, the [[Nebraska Supreme Court]] cleared the way for construction, after Republican Governor [[Dave Heineman]] had approved of it in 2013.{{cite news|title=Obama Facing Rising Pressure on Keystone Oil Pipeline|author1=CORAL DAVENPORT and MITCH SMITH|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/10/us/keystone-pipeline-nebraska-supreme-court-transcanada.html?_r=0|accessdate=12 January 2015|work=New York Times|publisher=NY times|date=9 January 2015}} A bill approving the construction of the Keystone XL Pipeline was passed by the Senate (62–36) on January 29, 2015, and by the House (270–152) on February 11, 2015. President Obama vetoed the bill on February 24, 2015, arguing that the decision of approval should rest with the Executive Branch.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/obama-vetoes-keystone-xl-pipeline-bill-n311671|title=Obama Vetoes Keystone XL Pipeline Bill|work=NBC News}} The Senate was unable to override the veto by a two-thirds majority, with a 62-37 vote.[http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/234615-senate-fails-to-override-obama-keystone-veto Keystone veto override fails]. March 4, 2015. [[File:Donald Trump signs orders to green-light the Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipelines.jpg|right|thumb|Trump signing the Presidential memoranda to advance the construction of the Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipelines. January 24th, 2017]] TransCanada sued Nebraska landowners who refused permission allowing for pipeline easements on their properties, in order to exercise [[eminent domain]] over such use. However, on September 29, 2015, it dropped its lawsuits and acceded to the authority of the elected, five-member [[Nebraska Public Service Commission]], which has the state constitutional authority to approve gas and oil pipelines.[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/30/us/keystone-xl-developer-drops-lawsuits.html Keystone XL developer drops lawsuits], [[Associated Press]], September 29, 2015. Retrieved 1 October 2015. On November 3, 2015, Secretary of State John Kerry issued a determination that the project was not in the public interest. Kerry found that there was a "perception" among foreigners that the project would increase greenhouse-gas emissions, and that, whether or not this perception was accurate, the decision would therefore "undercut the credibility and influence of the United States" in climate-change-related negotiations.{{cite web|last1=Kerry|first1=John|title=Department of State: Record of Decision and National Interest Determination|url=http://keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/documents/organization/249450.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121145230/http://keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/documents/organization/249450.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 November 2015|accessdate=8 January 2018}} On November 6, 2015, the Obama government rejected the pipeline.{{cite news|last1=Whitehouse|first1=Obama|title=Obama rejects TransCanada's Keystone XL pipeline|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2015/11/06/statement-president-keystone-xl-pipeline|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=Whitehouse|date=6 November 2015}} Early in his tenure, President [[Donald Trump]] signed presidential memoranda to revive both Keystone XL and [[Dakota Access Pipeline|Dakota Access]] pipelines. The order would expedite the environmental review that Trump described as an "incredibly cumbersome, long, horrible permitting process."{{cite news |last=Mufson |first=Steven |date=January 24, 2017 |title=Trump seeks to revive Dakota Access, Keystone XL oil pipelines |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2017/01/24/trump-gives-green-light-to-dakota-access-keystone-xl-oil-pipelines/ |newspaper=The Washington Post |location=Washington, DC |access-date=January 24, 2017}} Subsequently, Donald Trump signed a presidential permit to allow TransCanada to build the Keystone XL pipeline on March 24, 2017.{{cite news|last1=Jamieson|first1=Amber|last2=Vaughan|first2=Adam|title=Keystone XL: Trump issues permit to begin construction of pipeline|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/mar/24/keystone-xl-pipeline-permit-trump-administration|accessdate=March 24, 2017|newspaper=The Guardian|date=March 24, 2017}} On November 20, 2017, the Nebraska Public Service Commission approved (3-2) the construction of the pipeline, albeit through an alternative route that is longer, and was deemed to have the least environmental impact compared to two other routes that were considered.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/20/us/nebraska-keystone-xl-expansion/index.html|title=Nebraska approves path for controversial Keystone XL pipeline|last=CNN|first=Deanna Hackney and Holly Yan,|work=CNN|access-date=2017-12-02}} This proved to be a major setback for TransCanada since they would have "years of new review and legal challenges". TransCanada asked Nebraska to reconsider this decision{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-27/transcanada-asks-nebraska-to-reconsider-keystone-xl-route-ruling|title=TransCanada Asks Nebraska to Reconsider Keystone XL Ruling|date=2017-11-27|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-12-02}} and is currently working with Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA) to determine the structural cause of a leak in South Dakota on November 21.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/south-dakota-regulator-raises-prospect-of-revoking-keystone-permit-1512087617|title=South Dakota Regulator Raises Prospect of Revoking Keystone Permit|last=Monga|first=Vipal|date=2017-12-01|work=The Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-12-02|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660|url-access=subscription}} ==Keystone XL controversies== [[File:Bill McKibben KXL-Arrest.jpg|thumb|The [[environmentalist]] [[Bill McKibben]] ([[350.org]]) arrested in front of the White House at a protest against Keystone XL project.]] The Keystone XL proposal faced criticism from [[environmentalist]]s and a minority of the members of the [[United States Congress]]. In January 2012, President [[Barack Obama]] rejected the application amid protests about the pipeline's impact on Nebraska's environmentally sensitive Sandhills region.{{cite news | url = http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-11-08/transcanada-wins-as-obama-keystone-permit-seen | title = TransCanada Wins as Obama Keystone Permit Seen | newspaper = Bloomberg BusinessWeek | date = 2012-10-08 | accessdate = 2012-11-10 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121111190942/http://www.businessweek.com//news//2012-11-08//transcanada-wins-as-obama-keystone-permit-seen | archivedate = 2012-11-11 | df = }} [[TransCanada Corporation]] changed the original proposed route of Keystone XL to minimize "disturbance of land, water resources and special areas"; the new route was approved by Nebraska Governor [[Dave Heineman]] in January 2013. On April 18, 2014, the Obama administration announced that the review of the controversial Keystone XL oil pipeline has been extended indefinitely, pending the result of a legal challenge to a Nebraska pipeline siting law that could change the route. On January 9, 2015, the Nebraska Supreme Court cleared the way for construction, and on the same day the House voted in favor of the pipeline. On January 29, 2015, the Keystone XL Pipeline was passed by the Senate 62–36.Senate Passes Keystone XL Measure, [http://www.cnn.com/2015/01/29/politics/senate-keystone-final-vote/index.html], accessed Jan. 2015 On February 11, 2015, the Keystone XL Pipeline was passed by the House of Representatives with the proposed Senate Amendments 270–152.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/congress-set-pass-bill-approving-keystone-xl-pipeline-081015326--politics.html|title=Congress clears Keystone XL pipeline bill, setting up veto|date=10 February 2015|work=Yahoo News}} The Keystone XL Pipeline bill was not officially sent to President Obama, starting the official ten-day count towards the bill becoming law without presidential signature, until February 24, 2015. Republicans delayed delivering the bill over the Presidents Day holiday weekend to ensure Congress would be in session if the president were to veto the bill. On February 24, 2015, the bill was vetoed and returned for congressional action.[https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2015/02/24/388738159/obama-to-veto-keystone-xl-pipeline-today-without-drama-or-fanfare-or-delay Obama Vetoes Keystone XL Pipeline Bill]. 24 February 2015. Retrieved 24 February 2015. On March 4, 2015, the Senate held a vote and failed to override President Obama's veto of the bill; the vote was 62 to 37, less than the two-thirds majority required to override a presidential veto.{{Cite news|title= Senate Fails to Override Obama's Keystone Pipeline Veto |date=4 March 2015 |publisher=The New York Times |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/05/us/senate-fails-to-override-obamas-keystone-pipeline-veto.html |first=Coral |last=Davenport}} The review by the State Department is ongoing. On June 15, 2015 the House Oversight Committee threatened to subpoena the State Department for the latter's withholding of records relevant to the process since March 2015 and calling the process "unnecessarily secretive".{{cite web |url=http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/245018-gop-threatens-subpoena-for-keystone-record |title=:GOP Threatens to Subpoena State Department |publisher=The Hill }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Despite some records being posted by consulted agencies such as the EPA, the State Department has not responded to the request. On November 2, 2015, TransCanada asked the Obama administration to suspend its permit application for the Keystone XL.{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/transcanada-requests-suspension-of-u-s-permit-for-keystone-xl-pipeline-1446507279|title=TransCanada Requests Suspension of U.S. Permit for Keystone XL Pipeline|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=2 November 2015|date=2 November 2015}} In his speech announcing the rejection of the pipeline on November 6, 2015, President Obama lamented the symbolic importance Keystone XL had taken on, stating, "for years, the Keystone pipeline has occupied what I, frankly, consider an overinflated role in our political discourse. It became a symbol too often used as a campaign cudgel by both parties rather than a serious policy matter. And all of this obscured the fact that this pipeline would neither be a silver bullet for the economy, as was promised by some, nor the express lane to climate disaster proclaimed by others."{{cite press release |last=Office of the Press Secretary |date=2015-11-05 |title=Statement by the President on the Keystone XL Pipeline |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2015/11/06/statement-president-keystone-xl-pipeline |agency=The White House |access-date=2016-10-05}} President Obama nonetheless acknowledged the symbolic importance, going on to state, "frankly, approving this project would have undercut [the United States'] global leadership" on climate change.{{cite news|last1=Mathiesen|first1=Karl|title=Keystone XL pipeline rejection signals US taking lead on climate change fight|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/nov/07/keystone-xl-pipeline-rejection-signals-us-lead-climate-change|accessdate=5 October 2016|work=The Guardian|date=7 November 2015}} ===Environmental issues=== Different environmental groups, citizens, and politicians have raised concerns about the potential negative impacts of the Keystone XL project.{{cite web|publisher=Natural Resource Defense Council|title=Tar Sands and Safety Risk|url=http://www.nrdc.org/energy/tarsandssafetyrisks.asp|accessdate=22 November 2011}}{{cite web|publisher=[[Sierra Club]] Nebraska|title=XL Pipeline|url=http://sierranebraska.org/xl-pipeline/|accessdate=22 November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111202215732/http://sierranebraska.org/xl-pipeline/|archivedate=2 December 2011|df=}}{{cite press release|title=Gov. Heineman: Pipeline Re-Routing is Nebraska Common Sense|publisher=Office of Governor of Nebraska|url=http://www.governor.nebraska.gov/news/2011/11/15_pipline.html|date=15 November 2011|accessdate=22 November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111127060948/http://www.governor.nebraska.gov/news/2011/11/15_pipline.html|archivedate=27 November 2011|df=}} The main issues are the risk of oil spills along the pipeline, which would traverse highly sensitive terrain, and 17% higher [[greenhouse gas emissions]] from the extraction of [[oil sands]] compared to extraction of conventional oil.{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/22/opinion/tar-sands-and-the-carbon-numbers.html|title=Editorial: Tar Sands and the Carbon Numbers|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=2011-08-21|issn=0362-4331|accessdate=2012-11-26}}{{cite web|title=Draft Supplementary Environmental Impact Statement (SEIS)|url=http://keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/draftseis/index.htm|publisher=U.S. State Department|accessdate=12 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130304065248/http://keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/draftseis/index.htm|archivedate=4 March 2013|df=}} ====Potential for oil spills==== As of 2010, there were worries that a pipeline spill could pollute air and critical water supplies and harm migratory birds and other wildlife. Its original route plan crossed the [[Sandhills (Nebraska)|Sandhills]], the large wetland ecosystem in Nebraska, and the [[Ogallala Aquifer]], one of the largest reserves of [[fresh water]] in the world. {{cite report|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2011/11/176964.htm|publisher=U.S.State Department|title=Media Notes on Keystone XL Pipeline Project Review Process: Decision to Seek Additional Information|location=Washington, D.C.|date=November 10, 2011|accessdate=March 22, 2012}}{{cite news|title=World's Largest Aquifer Going Dry |url=http://www.uswaternews.com/archives/arcsupply/6worllarg2.html |date=February 2006 |work=U.S. Water News Online |accessdate=2010-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060913031104/http://www.uswaternews.com/archives/arcsupply/6worllarg2.html |archivedate=2006-09-13 |df= }} The Ogallala Aquifer spans eight states, provides [[drinking water]] for two million people, and supports $20 billion in agriculture.{{cite news |title= Ed Stelmach's Clumsy American Romance | url= https://thetyee.ca/Opinion/2010/07/07/StelmachsClumsyRomance/ | date= 2010-07-07 | newspaper = The Tyee | first = Mitchell | last= Anderson | accessdate= 2010-07-22}} Critics say that a major leak could ruin drinking water and devastate the mid-western U.S. economy.{{cite report|url=http://www.kdheks.gov/befs/download/bibliography/ksne_ecoregions.pdf|format = PDF|title=Level IV Ecoregions of Kansas and Nebraska|year=2001|access-date=March 26, 2012}}{{cite news | title= Gulf Disaster Raises Alarms about Alberta to Texas Pipeline | url= https://thetyee.ca/News/2010/06/21/AlbertaToTexasPipeline/ | date= 2010-06-21 | newspaper = The Tyee | first= Geoff | last= Dembicki | accessdate=2010-07-22}} After opposition for laying the pipeline in this area, TransCanada agreed to change the route and skip the Sandhills. University of Nebraska professor Dr. John Stansbury conducted an independent analysis that provides more detail on the potential risks for the Ogallala Aquifer.{{cite web |url=http://watercenter.unl.edu/downloads/2011-Worst-case-Keystone-spills-report.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150117101558/http://watercenter.unl.edu/downloads/2011-Worst-case-Keystone-spills-report.pdf |archivedate=2015-01-17 |df= }} In his [https://web.archive.org/web/20150117101558/http://watercenter.unl.edu/downloads/2011-Worst-case-Keystone-spills-report.pdf analysis], Dr. Stansbury concludes that safety assessments provided by TransCanada are misleading. According to Dr. Stansbury, "We can expect no fewer than 2 major spills per state during the 50-year projected lifetime of the pipeline. These spills could release as much as 180 thousand barrels of oil each."{{cite web|url=http://www.desmogblog.com/expert-warns-transcanada-s-keystone-xl-pipeline-assessments-are-misleading|title=Expert Warns That TransCanada's Keystone XL Pipeline Assessments Are Misleading|work=DeSmogBlog}} Other items of note in Dr. Stansbury's analysis: * "While TransCanada estimates that the Keystone XL will have 11 significant spills (more than 50 barrels of crude oil) over 50 years, a more realistic assessment is 91 significant spills over the pipeline's operational lifetime. TransCanada arbitrarily and improperly adjusted spill factors to produce an estimate of one major spill on the {{convert|1,673|mi|km|abbr=on}} of pipeline about every five years, but federal data on the actual incidence of spills on comparable pipelines indicate a more likely average of almost two major spills per year. (The existing Keystone I pipeline has had one major spill and 11 smaller spills in its first year of operation.)" * "Analysis of the time needed to shut down the pipeline shows that response to a leak at a river crossing could conservatively take more than ten times longer than the 11 minutes and 30 seconds that TransCanada assumes. (After the June 2010 spill of more than {{convert|800,000|USgal|L}} of crude oil into a tributary of the Kalamazoo River, an Enbridge tar sands pipeline – a {{convert|30|in|mm|adj=on}} pipe compared to the {{convert|36|in|mm|adj=on}} Keystone XL – was not completely shut down for 12 hours.)" * "Realistic calculations yield worst-case spill estimates of more than {{convert|180000|oilbbl|USgal L}} in the Nebraska Sandhills above the Ogallala Aquifer, more than {{convert|160000|oilbbl|USgal L}} of crude oil at the Yellowstone River crossings, more than {{convert|140000|oilbbl|USgal L}} at the Platte River crossing and more than {{convert|120000|oilbbl|USgal L}} at the Missouri River crossing." * "Contaminants from a release at the Missouri or Yellowstone River crossing would enter Lake Sakakawea in North Dakota where they would adversely affect drinking water intakes, aquatic wildlife, and recreation. Contaminants from a spill at the Platte River crossing would travel downstream unabated into the Missouri River for several hundred miles affecting drinking water intakes for hundreds of thousands of people (e.g., Lincoln, NE; Omaha, NE; Nebraska City, NE; St. Joseph, MO; Kansas City, MO) as well as aquatic habitats and recreational activities. In addition, other constituents from the spill would pose serious risks to humans and to aquatic species in the river." * "The worst-case site for such a spill is in the Sandhills region of Nebraska. The Sandhills are ancient sand dunes that have been stabilized by grasses. Because of their very permeable geology, nearly 100 percent of the annual rainfall infiltrates to a very shallow aquifer, often less than 20 feet below the surface. This aquifer is the well-known Ogallala Aquifer that is one of the most productive and important aquifers in the world." Pipeline industry spokesmen have noted that thousands of miles of existing pipelines carrying crude oil and refined liquid hydrocarbons have crossed over the Ogallala Aquifer for years, in southeast Wyoming, eastern Colorado and New Mexico, western Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, and Texas.Larry Lakely, [http://heartland.org/policy-documents/map-pipelines-and-ogallala-aquifer-2012 Map of Pipelines and the Ogallala Aquifer, 2012], 20 Jan. 2012. * Andrew Black and David Holt, [http://journalstar.com/news/opinion/editorial/columnists/guest-view-we-need-crude-oil-pipelines/article_767f684d-42ef-586e-97ec-557e6764e8a4.html Guest View: We need crude oil pipelines] ''Lincoln Journal Star'', 12 July 2011 * Allegro Energy Group, [http://www.pipeline101.com/reports/Notes.pdf How Pipelines Make the Oil Market Work – Their Networks, Operation and Regulation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228073802/http://www.pipeline101.com/reports/Notes.pdf |date=2013-12-28 }}, December 2001, Association of Oil Pipe Lines and American Petroleum Institute, pp. 8–9. * Pipeline 101, [http://www.pipeline101.com/Overview/products-pl.html Refined products pipelines], accessed 8 Oct. 2013. * Oil Sands fact Check, [http://oilsandsfactcheck.org/2012/05/30/myth-vs-fact-kxl-will-threaten-the-ogallala-aquifer/ Myth vs. Fact: KXL will Threaten the Ogallala Aquifer] 20 May 2012. The Pioneer crude oil pipeline crosses east-west across Nebraska, and the Pony Express pipeline, which crosses the Ogallala Aquifer in Colorado, Nebraska, and Kansas, was being converted as of 2013 from natural gas to crude oil, under a permit from the [[Federal Energy Regulatory Commission]].Paul Hammel, [https://archive.is/20131011165109/http://www.omaha.com/article/20120823/NEWS/708239899 Smaller oil pipeline to cross Ogallala Aquifer], Omaha.com, 23 Aug. 2012. Portions of the pipeline will also cross an active [[seismic zone]] that had a 4.3 magnitude [[earthquake]] as recently as 2002. Opponents claim that TransCanada applied to the U.S. government to use thinner steel and pump at higher pressures than normal. In October 2011, ''The New York Times'' questioned the impartiality of the environmental analysis of the pipeline done by [[Cardno Entrix]], an environmental contractor based in Houston. The study found that the pipeline would have limited adverse environmental impacts, but was authored by a firm that had "previously worked on projects with TransCanada and describes the pipeline company as a 'major client' in its marketing materials". {{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/08/science/earth/08pipeline.html?_r=1|title=Pipeline Review Is Faced With Question of Conflict|author=News|newspaper=The New York Times|date=2011-10-07|issn=0362-4331|accessdate=2011-10-31}} However, the Department of State's Office of the Inspector General conducted an investigation of the potential conflict of interest, and its February 2012 report of that investigation states there was no conflict of interest either in the selection of the contractor or in the preparation of the environmental impact statement.United States Department of State and the Broadcasting Board of Governors Office of Inspector General Office of Audits. February 2012. ''Special Review of the Keystone XL Pipeline Permit Process.'' Report Number AUD/SI-12-28. According to ''The New York Times'', legal experts questioned whether the U.S. government was "flouting the intent" of the Federal [[National Environmental Policy Act]], which "[was] meant to ensure an impartial environmental analysis of major projects". The report prompted 14 senators and congressmen to ask the State Department inspector general on October 26, 2011 "to investigate whether conflicts of interest tainted the process" for reviewing environmental impact.[http://sanders.senate.gov/newsroom/news/?id=BD202829-66E3-4088-A108-289E6E445CE9 Tar Sands Pipeline Probe Urged] Sen. Bernie Sanders October 26, 2011 In August 2014, a study was published that concluded the pipeline could produce up to 4 times more global warming pollution than the State Department's study indicated. The report blamed the discrepancy on a failure to take account of the increase in consumption due to the drop in the price of oil that would be spurred by the pipeline.{{cite web|last1=Associated Press|title=Study: Keystone pollution higher|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/08/study-keystone-pollution-highera-109892.html?hp=l20|website=www.politico.com|publisher=Politico|accessdate=11 August 2014}} TransCanada CEO Russ Girling has described the Keystone Pipeline as "routine", noting that TransCanada has been building similar pipelines in North America for half a century and that there are {{convert|200,000|mi}} of similar oil pipelines in the United States today. He also stated that the Keystone Pipeline will include 57 improvements above standard requirements demanded by U.S. regulators so far, making it "the safest pipeline ever built". Rep. [[Ed Whitfield]], a member of the [[House Committee on Energy and Commerce]] concurred, saying "this is the most technologically advanced and safest pipeline ever proposed."[https://web.archive.org/web/20120201052045/http://www.sunnewsnetwork.ca/sunnews/world/archives/2011/12/20111202-162023.html "Keystone XL the 'safest pipeline ever'"], ''[[Sun News Network]]'', 2 December 2011. However, while TransCanada had asserted that a set of 57 conditions will ensure Keystone XL's safe operation, Anthony Swift of the Natural Resources Defense Council asserted that all but a few of these conditions simply restate current minimum standards.{{cite news |url= http://insideclimatenews.org/news/20110919/keystone-xl-pipeline-safety-regulations-phmsa-transcanada-oil-sands-bitumen |title=Keystone XL Pipeline Safety Standards Not as Rigorous as They Seem |first = Elizabeth |last = McGowan |newspaper= InsideClimate News |date=2011-09-19|accessdate=2011-12-01}} TransCanada claims that they will take 100% responsibility for any potential environmental problems. According to their website, "It's our responsibility – as a good company and under law. If anything happens on the Keystone XL Pipeline, rapid response is key. That's why our Emergency Response plans are approved by state and federal agencies, and why we practice them regularly. We conduct regular emergency exercises, and aerial surveys every two weeks. We’re ready to respond with a highly-trained response team standing by." {{cite web |url=http://keystone-xl.com/facts/myths-facts/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150315010508/http://keystone-xl.com/facts/myths-facts/ |archivedate=2015-03-15 |df= }} ====Leaks and 2017 South Dakota spill==== In 2016, about 400 barrels were released from the original Keystone pipe network via leaks, which federal investigators said resulted from a "weld anomaly." On November 17, 2017, the pipeline leaked what the company claimed was 210,000 gallons of oil onto farmland near [[Amherst, South Dakota]]. The oil leak is the largest seen from the Keystone pipeline in the state. The leak lasted for several minutes, with no initial reports of damage to water sources or wildlife. Although the spill did not happen on Sioux property, it was in close enough proximity to potentially contaminate the aquifer used for water.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/16/us/keystone-pipeline-leak/index.html|title=Keystone Pipeline leaks 210,000 gallons of oil in South Dakota|last=CNN|first=Mayra Cuevas and Steve Almasy,|work=CNN|access-date=2017-11-17}}{{cite news |last1=Mufson|first1=Steven|last2=Mooney|first2=Chris |date=2017-11-16|title=Keystone pipeline spills 210,000 gallons of oil on eve of permitting decision for TransCanada|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2017/11/16/keystone-pipeline-spills-210000-gallons-of-oil-on-eve-of-key-permitting-decision/|work=[[The Washington Post]] |location= |access-date=2017-11-18}} The pipeline was immediately shut down,[https://mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUSKBN1HE0T7?__twitter_impression=true "Keystone pipeline leak in South Dakota about double previous estimate: paper"], Reuters, April 7, 2018 and TransCanada began using the pipe again 12 days after the leak.[https://www.greatfallstribune.com/story/news/2018/04/07/keystone-pipeline-spill-south-dakota-twice-big-first-thought/496679002/ "Keystone Pipeline spill in South Dakota twice as big as first thought"], Associated Press, April 7, 2018 For much of late 2017, the Keystone pipeline operated at reduced pressure during remediation efforts. The federal [[Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration]] said that the failure "may have been caused by mechanical damage to the pipeline and coating associated with a weight installed on the pipeline in 2008." Later, the NTSB found that a metal tracked vehicle had run over the area, damaging the pipeline.https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PAB1801.pdf[https://www.upi.com/November-spill-from-Keystone-pipeline-larger-than-first-estimated/8971523274440/ "November spill from Keystone pipeline larger than first estimated"], Daniel J. Graeber, UPI, April 9, 2018 In April 2018, a federal investigation found that 408,000 gallons of crude had spilled at the site, almost twice what TransCanada had reported. That number made it the seventh-largest onshore oil spill since 2002.[https://news.vice.com/en_us/article/evqqmk/egypts-jon-stewart-watched-the-egyptian-elections-from-la "The Keystone Pipeline oil spill was nearly twice as big as TransCanada said"], ''[[Vice News]]'', Sarah Sax, April 10, 2018https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_32334.html?nocache=5134#_Incidents_tab_3 In April 2018, ''[[Reuters]]'' reviewed documents that showed that Keystone had "leaked substantially more oil, and more often, in the United States than the company indicated to regulators in risk assessments before operations began in 2010." ====Potential for increased carbon emissions==== Environmental organizations such as the [[Natural Resources Defense Council]] (NRDC) also oppose the project due to its transportation of oil from oil sands. In its March 2010 report, the NRDC stated that "the Keystone XL Pipeline undermines the U.S. commitment to a [[clean energy]] economy", instead "delivering dirty fuel at high costs".{{cite news |title= Say No to Tar Sands Pipeline | url= http://www.nrdc.org/land/files/TarSandsPipeline4pgr.pdf | date= 2010-03-10 | publisher= NRDC | format = PDF | accessdate= 2010-07-22}} On June 23, 2010, 50 Democrats in Congress in their letter to Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] warned that "building this pipeline has the potential to undermine America's clean energy future and international leadership on climate change", referencing the higher input quantity of fossil fuels [[Oil sands#Input energy|necessary to take the tar and turn it into a usable fuel product]] in comparison to other [[Energy returned on energy invested|conventionally derived fossil fuels]].{{cite news | url = http://switchboard.nrdc.org/blogs/sclefkowitz/house_members_say_proposed_tar_1.html | title = House members say tar sands pipeline will undermine clean energy future | publisher = NRDC | first = Susan | last = Casey-Lefkowitz | date = 2010-06-23 | accessdate = 2010-07-27}}{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=23134 | title = Enviro Groups, 50 Congressmen Mobilize Against Keystone XL | newspaper = The Commercial Appeal | first = Bartholomew | last = Sullivan | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2010-06-24 | accessdate = 2010-08-01}} [[NASA]] climate scientist [[James Hansen]] stated in 2013 that "moving to tar sands, one of the dirtiest, most [[EROEI|carbon-intensive fuels]] on the planet" is a step in exactly the wrong direction, "indicating either that governments don't understand the situation or that they just don't give a damn". {{cite news | url = http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=tar-sands-and-keystone-xl-pipeline-impact-on-global-warming | title = How Much Will Tar Sands Oil Add to Global Warming? | work = [[Scientific American]] | first = Davied | last = Biello | date = 2013-01-23 | accessdate = 2013-04-24}} The [[House Energy and Commerce Committee]]'s chairman at the time, Representative [[Henry Waxman]], had also urged the State Department to block Keystone XL for greenhouse gas emission reasons.{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN0611124720100706 | title = Key US lawmaker opposes Canadian oil sands pipeline | agency = Reuters | first1 = Ayesha | last1 = Rascoe | first2 = Scott | last2 = Haggett | date = 2010-07-06 | accessdate = 2010-07-27}}{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=23312 | title = Oil Sands Push Tests US-Canada Ties | newspaper = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | first1 = Phred | last1 = Dvorak | first2 = Edward | last2 = Welsch | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2010-07-08 | accessdate = 2010-08-01}} In December 2010, the No Tar Sands Oil campaign, sponsored by action groups including Corporate Ethics International, NRDC, [[Sierra Club]], [[350.org]], [[National Wildlife Federation]], [[Friends of the Earth]], [[Greenpeace]], and [[Rainforest Action Network]], was launched.{{cite news | url = http://www.commondreams.org/headline/2010/12/08-6 | title = Pressure in U.S. mounts against oilsands pipeline | first = Dina | last = O'Meara | newspaper = [[The Calgary Herald]] | date = 2010-12-08 | accessdate = 2012-01-20}} In a speech to the Canadian Club in Toronto on September 23, 2011, [[Joe Oliver (politician)|Joe Oliver]], [[Minister of Natural Resources (Canada)|Canada's Minister of Natural Resources]], sharply criticized opponents of oil sands development and the pipeline, arguing that:{{cite news |title=NOTA Bene |url=http://www.nationalpost.com/news/NOTA+Bene/5452294/story.html |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20110924221506/http://www.nationalpost.com/news/NOTA+Bene/5452294/story.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 September 2011 |newspaper=National Post |date=24 September 2011 |accessdate=10 August 2013 |df= }} * The total area that has been affected by surface mining represents only 0.1% of [[Boreal forest of Canada|Canada's boreal forest]]. * The oil sands account for about 0.1% of global greenhouse-gas emissions. * Electricity plants powered by coal in the U.S. generate almost 40 times more greenhouse-gas emissions than Canada's oil sands (the coal-fired electricity plants in the State of Wisconsin alone produce the equivalent of the entire GHG emissions of the oil sands). * California bitumen is more GHG-intensive than the oil sands. The State Department's Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement (Final SEIS) estimated that producing and transporting oil to the pipeline's capacity would increase greenhouse-gas emissions compared to alternative sources of oil. However, this estimate would only apply to the pipeline project as a whole if the denial of the pipeline project meant that the oil would stay in the ground. "However, [...] such a change is not likely to occur. [A]pproval or denial of any one crude oil transport project, including the proposed Project, is unlikely to significantly impact the rate of extraction in the oil sands, or the continued demand for heavy crude oil." {{cite web|title=Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement, Keystone XL Project, 4.14: Greenhouse Gases and Climate Change|url=https://2012-keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/documents/organization/221190.pdf}} To the extent that the oil would be extracted in any case, the relevant comparison would be to alternative means of transporting it; the Final SEIS considered three alternative scenarios and found that "total GHG emissions associated with construction and operation (direct and indirect) combined would be higher for each of the three scenarios than for the entire route encompassing the proposed Project."{{cite web|title=Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement , Keystone XL Project, 5.3: Comparison of Alternatives|url=https://2012-keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/documents/organization/221198.pdf}} The Final SEIS made no estimate of the net effect of the project on greenhouse-gas emissions, considering both the amount of oil that would likely replace other sources (increasing emissions) and the amount of oil for which the pipeline would merely replace alternate means of transportation (decreasing emissions). In a February 2, 2015 letter response to the U.S. Department of State's [http://keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/finalseis/index.htm Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement (Final SEIS)] for the Keystone XL Pipeline Project, [http://www.epa.gov/ U.S. the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)] stated that the pipeline will significantly increase greenhouse gas emissions because it will lead to the expansion of Alberta's carbon intensive oilsands.{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/business/slams+Keystone+significant+emissions+climate+change+impact/10784258/story.html|title=EPA slams Keystone for 'significant' emissions and climate change impact|work=www.canada.com}} The letter goes on to add that over the proposed 50-year timeline of the pipeline, this could mean releasing as much as "1.37 billion more tons of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere".{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/02/03/epa-keystone-xl-pipeline-will-impact-global-warming|title=EPA: Keystone XL Pipeline Will Impact Global Warming - US News|author=Alan Neuhauser|work=US News & World Report}} According to the New York Times, EPA concluded that due to the current relatively cheap cost of oil, companies might be less likely to set up their own developments in the oil sands. It would be too expensive for the companies to ship by rail. However, "the presence of the pipeline, which offers an inexpensive way to move the oil to market, could increase the likelihood that companies would extract from the oil sands even when prices are low".{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/12/us/politics/house-passes-keystone-bill.html|title=House Passes Keystone Bill Despite Obama’s Opposition|date=12 February 2015|work=The New York Times}} In its letter response, the EPA suggested that the State Department should "revisit" its prior conclusions in light of the drop in oil prices.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/transcanada-rebuts-epa-comments-on-keystone-xl-pipeline-1423659353?mod=pls_whats_news_us_business_f|title=TransCanada Rebuts EPA Comments on Keystone XL Pipeline|author=Amy Harder and Lee Roberts|date=11 February 2015|work=WSJ}} TransCanada Corporation responded with a letter of its own, in which President and CEO Russel K.
