Girling stated that TransCanada "rejects the EPA inference that at lower oil prices the [Keystone XL Pipeline] Project will increase the rate of oil sands production growth and accompanying greenhouse gas emissions".http://keystone-xl.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/response-to-epa-letter.pdf Girling maintained that the EPA's conclusions "are not supported by the facts outlined in the Final SEIS or actual observations of the marketplace". ===Conflicts of interest=== On May 4, 2012, the U.S. Department of State selected Environmental Resources Management (ERM) to author a Draft Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement, after the Environmental Protection Agency had found previous versions of the study, by contractor Cardno Entrix,{{cite web|url=http://www.keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/|title=keystonepipelinexl|publisher=}} to be extremely inadequate.{{cite news | url = http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2012/02/keystone-xl-state-department-audit.html | title = Keystone XL: State Department cleared of conflict, not ineptness | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = 2012-02-09 | accessdate = 2012-11-27}} Project opponents panned the study on its release, calling it a "deeply flawed analysis".{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/mar/02/keystone-xl-pipeline-report-activists-scientists |title=Keystone XL pipeline report slammed by activists and scientists |first=Paul |last=Harris |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=2013-03-02 |location=London |issn=0261-3077 |oclc=60623878 |accessdate=2013-03-09}} An investigation by [[Mother Jones (magazine)]] revealed that the State Department had redacted the biographies of the study's authors to hide their previous contract work for TransCanada and other oil companies with an economic interest in the project.{{cite news |url= https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2013/03/keystone-xl-contractor-ties-transcanada-state-department |title=EXCLUSIVE: State Dept. Hid Contractor's Ties to Keystone XL Pipeline Company |first=Andy |last=Kroll |work=Mother Jones |date=21 March 2013 |publisher=Mother Jones and the Foundation for National Progress |location=[[San Francisco]] |accessdate=2013-04-24}} Based on an analysis of public documents on the State Department website, one critic asserted that "Environmental Resources Management was paid an undisclosed amount under contract to TransCanada to write the statement".{{cite web |url=http://grist.org/article/state-department-keystone-xl-report-actually-written-by-transcanada-contractor/ |title='State Department' Keystone XL Report Actually Written By TransCanada Contractor |first=Brad |last=Johnson |work=grist.org |year=2013 |accessdate=9 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130311104131/http://grist.org/article/state-department-keystone-xl-report-actually-written-by-transcanada-contractor/ |archivedate=11 March 2013 |df= }} ===Political issues=== [[File:Keystone Pipeline vote, House of Representatives, Nov. 14th 2014.png|thumb|right|Map showing how the United States House of Representatives voted on the Keystone Pipeline, November 14, 2014 : red=No, green=Yes]] The pipeline was a top-tier election issue for the November 4, 2014, United States elections for the [[United States Senate]], [[United States House of Representatives elections, 2014|for U.S. House of Representatives]], [[United States gubernatorial elections, 2014|for governors in states and territories]], and for many state and local positions as well. One election-year dilemma facing the Democrats was whether or not Obama should approve the completion of the Keystone XL pipeline.{{citation|title=Senate Democrats Urge Obama To Approve Keystone XL|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/10/senate-democrats-obama-keystone_n_5128187.html|date=2014-04-10|accessdate=2014-04-22|publisher=Huffington Post|first=Matthew |last=Daly|location=Washington, DC}} Tom Steyer, and other wealthy environmentalists, were committed to "make climate change a top-tier issue" in the elections with opposition to Keystone XL as "a significant part of that effort." In the election, the Republican party gained 13 House seats (gaining their largest majority in the House since 1928) and 9 Senate seats (becoming the majority party therein). In February 2011, environmental journalist David Sassoon of ''Inside Climate News'' reported that [[Koch Industries]] were poised to be "big winners" from the pipeline.{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/idUS292515702420110210 |title=Koch Brothers Positioned To Be Big Winners If Keystone XL Pipeline Is Approved |first= David |last= Sassoon |agency =Reuters |date=2011-02-10 |accessdate=2011-08-25}} In May 2011, Congressmen [[Henry Waxman|Waxman]] and [[Bobby Rush|Rush]] wrote a letter to the [[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce|Energy and Commerce Committee]] citing the Reuters story, and urging the Committee to request documents from Koch Industries relating to the Keystone XL pipeline.{{cite web |url= http://democrats.energycommerce.house.gov/index.php?q=news/reps-waxman-and-rush-urge-committee-to-request-documents-from-koch-industries-regarding-keystone |title= Reps. Waxman and Rush Urge Committee to Request Documents from Koch Industries Regarding Keystone XL Pipeline |publisher= Committee on Energy and Commerce Democrats |first= Henry A. |last= Waxman |first2= Bobby L. |last2= Rush |date= 2011-05-20 |accessdate= 2011-08-25 }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web |url= http://motherjones.com/blue-marble/2011/05/will-kochs-benefit-proposed-tar-sands-pipeline |title=Waxman Targets the Koch Brothers |first=Kate |last=Sheppard |publisher=Mother Jones |date= 2011-05-23 |accessdate=2011-08-25}} Landowners in the path of the pipeline have complained about threats by TransCanada to confiscate private land and lawsuits to allow the "pipeline on their property even though the controversial project has yet to receive federal approval". As of October 17, 2011, TransCanada had "34 [[eminent domain]] actions against landowners in Texas" and "22 in South Dakota". Some of those landowners gave testimony for a [[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce|House Energy and Commerce Committee]] hearing in May 2011. {{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/18/us/transcanada-in-eminent-domain-fight-over-pipeline.html?pagewanted=all |title= Eminent Domain Fight Has a Canadian Twist |newspaper = [[The New York Times]] |first1 = Leslie | last1 = Kaufman |first2 = Dan | last2 = Frosch |date = 2011-10-17 |accessdate=2011-10-31}} In his book ''The Pipeline and the Paradigm'', Samuel Avery quotes landowner David Daniel in Texas, who claims that TransCanada illegally seized his land via eminent domain by claiming to be a public utility rather than a private firm.{{cite book|last=Avery|first=Samuel|title=The Pipeline and the Paradigm|year=2013|publisher=Ruka Press|isbn=978-0-9855748-2-6|page=147|url=http://www.rukapress.com/books/the-pipeline-and-the-paradigm/}} In January 2012, Presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and Rep. Steve Cohen (D-Tenn.) requested a new report on the environmental review process.http://search.proquest.com/docview/920768194 In September 2015, Presidential candidate [[Hillary Clinton]] publicly expressed her opposition on Keystone XL, citing climate change concerns.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/09/22/politics/hillary-clinton-opposes-keystone-xl-pipeline/index.html|title=Hillary Clinton opposes Keystone XL pipeline|first=Eric Bradner, Dan Merica and Brianna Keilar|last=CNN|publisher=}} ===Diplomatic issues=== Commentator Bill Mann has linked the Keystone postponement to the Michigan Senate's rejection of Canadian funding for the proposed [[Gordie Howe International Bridge]] and to other recent instances of "U.S. government actions (and inactions) that show little concern about Canadian concerns". Mann drew attention to a ''[[Maclean's]]'' article sub-titled "we used to be friends"Mann, Bill, [http://www.marketwatch.com/story/americans-should-be-thankful-for-canada-2011-11-24 "Americans should be thankful for Canada"], ''[[MarketWatch]]'', November 24, 2011. Retrieved 2011-11-24. about U.S./Canada relations after President Obama had "insulted Canada (yet again)" over the pipeline.Savage, Luiza Ch., [http://www2.macleans.ca/2011/11/21/friends-like-these/ "The U.S. and Canada: we used to be friends"], ''[[Maclean's]]'', November 21, 2011 8:00 am. Retrieved 2011-11-24. Canadian [[Gary Doer|Ambassador Doer]] observes that Obama's "choice is to have it come down by a pipeline that he approves, or without his approval, it comes down on trains".{{cite news | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/energy-and-resources/transcanada-says-keystone-xl-will-create-many-jobs-despite-obama-interview/article13471894/ | title='Trains or pipelines,' Doer warns U.S. over Keystone | newspaper=The Globe & Mail | date = 2013-07-28 | location=Toronto}} During the 2014 Pacific Northwest Economic Region Summit in [[Whistler, British Columbia|Whistler, B.C.]], Canada's US Ambassador Gary Doer stated that there is no proof, be it environmental, economic, safety or scientific, that construction work on Keystone XL should not go ahead. Doer said that all the evidence supports a favourable decision by the US government for the controversial pipeline.{{cite web|title=Canada's US ambassador pushes for Keystone XL decision|url=http://www.energyglobal.com/news/pipelines/articles/Canadas-US-ambassador-pushes-for-Keystone-XL-decision-674.aspx#.U9if__ldV8E|date=July 24, 2014|publisher=energyglobal.com}} In contrast, the President of the [[Rosebud Indian Reservation|Rosebud Sioux Nation]], Cyril Scott, has stated that the November 14, 2014, vote in favor of the Keystone XL pipeline in the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] is an "[[Casus belli|act of war]]", declaring:
We are outraged at the lack of intergovernmental cooperation. We are a [[Westphalian sovereignty|sovereign nation]], and we are not being treated as such. We will close our reservation borders to Keystone XL. Authorizing Keystone XL is an act of war against our people.{{Cite news | title = Rosebud Sioux Tribe Calls House Keystone XL Passage an 'Act of War,' Vows Legal Action | work = Indian Country Today Media Network | accessdate = 2014-12-16 | date = 2014-11-17 | url = http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2014/11/17/rosebud-sioux-tribe-calls-house-keystone-xl-passage-act-war-vows-legal-action-157878 }}
===Geopolitical issues=== Proponents for the Keystone XL pipeline argue that it would allow the U.S. to increase its energy security and reduce its dependence on foreign oil.{{cite web |url=http://energycommerce.house.gov/keystonexl.shtml |title=U.S. House of Representatives, Committee on Energy and Commerce: The Keystone XL Pipeline |publisher=U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Energy and Commerce |accessdate=2012-01-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113045908/http://energycommerce.house.gov/keystonexl.shtml |archivedate=2012-01-13 |df= }}{{cite news |url= https://www.usatoday.com/news/opinion/editorials/story/2011-10-26/Keystone-oil-pipeline-build/50941230/1 |title=Say Yes To Building The Keystone Oil Pipeline |last= Editorial |agency =USA Today |date=2011-10-26 |accessdate=2012-01-10}} TransCanada CEO Russ Girling has argued that "the U.S. needs 10 million barrels a day of imported oil" and the debate over the proposed pipeline "is not a debate of oil versus alternative energy. This is a debate about whether you want to get your oil from Canada or [[Venezuela]] or [[Nigeria]]."{{cite news |url=http://www.financialpost.com/news/Keystone+exaggerated+rhetoric+untrue+Canada/5449012/story.html|title=Keystone 'exaggerated rhetoric' untrue|first=Yadullah |last=Hussein|newspaper= Financial Post |date=2011-09-23}} However, an independent study conducted by the Cornell ILR Global Labor Institute refers to some studies (e.g. a 2011 study by Danielle Droitsch of Pembina Institute) according to which "a good portion of the oil that will gush down the KXL will probably end up being finally consumed beyond the territorial United States". It also states that the project will increase the heavy crude oil price in the [[Midwestern United States]] by diverting oil sands oil from the Midwest refineries to the Gulf Coast and export markets.{{cite journal |url= http://www.ilr.cornell.edu/globallaborinstitute/research/upload/GLI_KeystoneXL_Reportpdf.pdf |title= Pipe dreams? Jobs Gained, Jobs Lost by the Construction of Keystone XL |publisher= [[Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations|ILR School Global Labor Institute]] |format = PDF |pages = 3, 27 |date=September 2011 |accessdate=2011-10-12}} The US Gulf Coast has a large concentration of refineries designed to process very heavy crude oil. At present, the refineries are dependent on heavy crude from [[Venezuela]], including crude from Venezuela's own massive [[Orinoco oil sands]]. The United States is the number one buyer of crude oil exported from Venezuela.US Energy Information Administration, [http://www.eia.gov/countries/cab.cfm?fips=ve Venezuela], 20 June 2014. The large trade relationship between the US and Venezuela has persisted despite political tensions between the two countries. However, the volume of oil imported into the US from Venezuela dropped in half from 2007 to 2014, as overall Venezuelan exports have dropped, and also as Venezuela seeks to become less dependent on US purchases of its crude oil. The Keystone pipeline is seen as a way to replace imports of heavy oil-sand crude from Venezuela with more reliable Canadian heavy oil.Jorge R. Pinon, [http://www.jsg.utexas.edu/lacp/files/UT-LACP-August-2014-Energy-Issue-Brief.pdf The possible loss of Venezuelan heavy crude oil imports underscores the strategic importance of the Keystone XL pipeline], Energy Issue Brief, Jackson School of Geosciences, Univ. of Texas, Aug. 2014. TransCanada's Girling has also argued that if Canadian oil doesn't reach the Gulf through an environmentally friendly buried pipeline, that the alternative is oil that will be brought in by tanker, a mode of transportation that produces higher greenhouse-gas emissions and that puts the environment at greater risk.{{cite news|url=http://business.financialpost.com/2011/09/08/transcanada-in-eye-of-the-storm/|title=TransCanada in eye of the storm|first=Claudia |last=Cattaneo |newspaper=Financial Post |date=September 9, 2011}} [[Diane Francis]] has argued that much of the opposition to the oil sands actually comes from foreign countries such as Nigeria, Venezuela, and Saudi Arabia, all of whom supply oil to the United States and who could be affected if the price of oil drops due to the new availability of oil from the pipeline. She cited as an example an effort by Saudi Arabia to stop pro-oil-sands television commercials.{{cite news | url = http://opinion.financialpost.com/2011/09/23/foreign-interests-attack-oil-sands/ | title = Foreign interests attack oil sands | newspaper=Financial Post | first = Diane | last = Francis | authorlink = Diane Francis | date = 2011-09-23 | accessdate = 2012-11-29}} TransCanada had said that development of oil sands will expand regardless of whether the crude oil is exported to the United States or alternatively to Asian markets through [[Enbridge Northern Gateway Pipelines]] or [[Kinder Morgan]]'s Trans-Mountain line.{{cite news | url = http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=23197 | title = TransCanada: Oil Sands Exports Will Go To Asia If Blocked In US | agency = [[Dow Jones Newswires]] | first = Edward | last = Welsch | publisher = Downstream Today | date = 2010-06-30 | accessdate = 2010-08-01}} ===Indigenous issues=== Many Native Americans and Indigenous Canadians are opposed to the Keystone XL project for various reasons,{{Cite web|title=Keystone XL Pipeline and Indigenous Peoples|url=http://indigenouspeoplesissues.com/index.php?searchword=Keystone%20XL&ordering=newest&searchphrase=exact&limit=20&option=com_search|work=Indigenous Peoples Issues and Resources|accessdate=31 May 2013}} including possible damage to sacred sites, pollution, and water contamination, which could lead to health risks among their communities.{{Cite web|title=First Nations and American Indian Leaders Arrested In Front Of White House To Protest Keystone XL Pipeline|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?action=interpret&id=GALE%7CA268095037&v=2.1&u=cuny_hunter&it=r&p=AONE&sw=w&authCount=1|work=Bioterrorism Week. (Sept. 19, 2011): p11.|publisher=Academic OneFile|accessdate=23 April 2012}} On September 19, 2011, a number of leaders from Native American bands in the United States and First Nations bands from Canada were arrested for protesting the Keystone XL outside the White House. According to Debra White Plume, a [[Lakota people|Lakota]] activist, indigenous peoples "have thousands of ancient and historical cultural resources that would be destroyed across [their] treaty lands". TransCanada's Pipeline Permit Application to the [[South Dakota Public Utilities Commission]] states project impacts that include potential physical disturbance, demolition or removal of "prehistoric or historic archaeological sites, districts, buildings, structures, objects, and locations with traditional cultural value to Native Americans and other groups".{{Cite web|title=Application to the South Dakota Public Utilities Commission for a Permit for the Keystone XL Pipeline Under the Energy Conversion and Transmission Facility Act|url=http://puc.sd.gov/commission/dockets/hydrocarbonpipeline/2009/hp09-001/application.pdf|publisher=puc.sd.gov|accessdate=23 April 2012}} Indigenous communities are also concerned with health risks posed by the extension of the Keystone pipeline.{{Cite web|title=Tar Sands Pipeline Safety Risks |url=http://pstrust.org/docs/TarSandsPipelineSafetyRisksFINALFINAL.pdf.pdf |publisher=National Resources Defense Council |accessdate=10 August 2013 |first1=Anthony |last1=Swift |first2=Susan |last2=Casey-Lefkowitz |first3=Elizabeth |last3=Shope |date=February 2011 |format=PDF}} Locally caught fish and untreated surface water would be at risk for contamination through oil sands extraction, and are central to the diets of many indigenous peoples.{{Cite web|last=Timoney|first=Kevin P.|title=A Study of Water and Sediment Quality as Related to Public Health Issues |url=http://www.upr-info.org/sites/default/files/document/canada/session_04_-_february_2009/acfn_can_upr_s4_2009_anx_drtimoneyreportonfortchip.pdf|work=Treeline Ecological Research|publisher=www.tothetarsands.ca|accessdate=23 March 2015}} Earl Hatley, an environmental activist who has worked with Native American tribes{{Cite web|title=Earl Hatley: Portrait of an Oklahoma activist|url=http://www.currentland.com/ViewArticle/6/Default.aspx|work=The Current|publisher=www.currentland.com|accessdate=26 April 2012}} has expressed concern about the environmental and public health impact on Native Americans. TransCanada has developed an Aboriginal Relations policy in order to confront some of these conflicts. In 2004, TransCanada made a major donation to the [[University of Toronto]] "to promote education and research in the health of the Aboriginal population".{{Cite journal|title=New Appointments in Aboriginal Health at the University of Toronto|journal=International Journal of Circumpolar Health|year=2004|volume=e{{ISSN|2242-3982}} (print volumes from 1972–2011: {{ISSN|1239-9736}})|issue=Circumpolar Health Supplements|page=294|url=http://www.circumpolarhealthjournal.net/index.php/ijch/article/view/17741/20209|accessdate=23 April 2012}} Another proposed solution is TransCanada's Aboriginal Human Resource Strategy, which was developed to facilitate aboriginal employment and to provide "opportunities for Aboriginal businesses to participate in both the construction of new facilities and the ongoing maintenance of existing facilities".{{Cite web|author=TransCanada|title=Community, Aboriginal and Native American Relations|url=http://www.transcanada.com/662.html|publisher=TransCanada.com|accessdate=23 April 2012}} ===Economic issues=== [[Russ Girling]], president and CEO of [[TransCanada Corp.|TransCanada]], touted the positive impact of the project by "putting 20,000 US workers to work and spending $7 billion stimulating the US economy".{{cite video | date = 2011-08-31 | title = TransCanada CEO on Proposed Pipeline | url = http://video.foxbusiness.com/v/1136627843001/transcanada-ceo-on-proposed-pipeline/ | publisher = [[Fox News Channel]] | accessdate = 2011-10-12}} These numbers come from a 2010 report written by The Perryman Group, a financial analysis firm based in Texas that was hired by TransCanada to evaluate Keystone XL.{{cite report | date = June 2010 | title = The Impact of Developing the Keystone XL Pipeline Project on Business Activity in the US: An Analysis Including State-by-State Construction Effects and an Assessment of the Potential Benefits of a More Stable Source of Domestic Supply | url = http://www.perrymangroup.com/reports/TransCanada.pdf | publisher = Perryman Group | accessdate = 2012-03-18 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120125125858/http://www.perrymangroup.com/reports/TransCanada.pdf | archivedate = 2012-01-25 | df = }}{{cite journal | date = 2012-01-12 | title = Keystone XL Jobs Bewilder Media. Reporters still fumbling numbers in wake of pipeline's rejection | author = Brainard, Curtis | url = http://www.cjr.org/the_observatory/keystone_xl_jobs_bewilder_medi.php?page=all&print=true | work = The Observatory | publisher = [[Columbia Journalism Review]] | accessdate = 2012-03-18}} The numbers in the Perryman Group report have been disputed by an independent study conducted by the [[Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations|Cornell ILR Global Labor Institute]], which found that while the Keystone XL would result in 2,500 to 4,650 temporary construction jobs, this impact will be reduced by higher oil prices in the Midwest, which will likely reduce national employment. However, it will increase gasoline availability to the Northeast and expand the Gulf refining industry. The State Department estimates that the pipeline would create about 5,000 to 6,000 temporary jobs in the United States during the two-year construction period. {{cite news | date = 2012-01-19 | title = Keystone pipeline: How many jobs really at stake? | author = Sherter, Alain | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505123_162-57361212/keystone-pipeline-how-many-jobs-really-at-stake/ | publisher = [[CBS News]] | accessdate = 2012-03-18}}{{Cite news | url=http://money.cnn.com/2011/12/13/news/economy/keystone_pipeline_jobs/index.htm | work=CNN | first=Steve | last=Hargreaves | title=Keystone pipeline: How many jobs it would really create | date=2011-12-14 | accessdate = 2012-12-01}} On January 27, 2012, Greenpeace Executive Director [[Phil Radford]] appealed to the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] to review TransCanada's claims that the Keystone Pipeline would create 20,000 jobs. Stating that the company had "consistently used public statements and information it knows are false in a concerted effort to secure permitting approval" of the pipeline, Radford argued that TransCanada had "misled investors, U.S. and Canadian officials, the media, and the public at large in order to bolster its balance sheets and share price".{{Cite news | author = Radford, Phil |title=Greenpeace Letter to Securities and Exchange Commission | url = https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/287168-gp-sec-transcanada-letter.html | accessdate = 2014-03-04|date=2012-01-26}} On July 27, 2013, President Obama stated "The most realistic estimates are this might create maybe 2,000 jobs during the construction of the pipeline, which might take a year or two, and then after that we're talking about somewhere between 50 and 100 jobs in an economy of 150 million working people." The estimate of 2,000 during construction came under heavy attack, while the long-term, permanent job estimates did not receive as much criticism.{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/27/obama-keystone-xl-jobs_n_3664998.html |title=Obama Questions Keystone XL Pipeline Job Projections|date=2013-07-27 |accessdate=2013-08-11 |work=Huffington Post}} The Associated Press noted that it was unclear where the president's figure of 2,000 jobs came from. The U.S. State Department's Preliminary Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement, issued in March 2013, estimated 3,900 direct jobs and 42,000 direct and indirect jobs during construction.Associated Press, [http://washington.cbslocal.com/2013/08/01/ap-obama-understates-keystone-xl-pipeline-jobs-by-thousands/ AP: Obama Understates Keystone XL Pipeline Jobs By Thousands], 1 Aug. 2013 According to the [http://keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/finalseis/ Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement (SEIS)], the Pipeline will only create 35 permanent jobs.{{cite web|url=http://keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/finalseis/|title=Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement (SEIS)|work=state.gov}} There might be unintended economic consequences to the construction of Keystone XL. As an example, the additional north-south crude oil transport capacity brought by Keystone XL will increase the price the oil sands producers receive for their oil. These higher revenues will have a positive impact on the development of the industry in Alberta. In return, due to the [[Petrodollar]] nature of the Canadian currency these same additional revenues will strengthen the [[Canadian dollar]] versus the [[United States dollar]]. Based on historical trends, this stronger Canadian dollar will result in a reduction of the competitiveness of Canada's manufacturing industry and could lead to the loss of 50,000 to 100,000 jobs in Canada's manufacturing sector.{{Cite web | title = On the economic impact of the Keystone pipeline | url = http://opendatadepot.org/blog/entry/7/on-the-economic-impact-of-the-keystone-pipeline/ | accessdate = 2013-03-19}}{{unreliable source?|reason=anonymous blog|date=March 2013}} Many of these jobs, such as the ones in the auto industry, would likely find their way south and have a positive impact on manufacturing employment in the U.S.{{Cite news | last = Cato | first = Jeremy | title = Canadian Auto Workers union: singing off-key as jobs go south | newspaper = [[The Globe and Mail]] | date = September 10, 2012 | url = http://m.theglobeandmail.com/globe-drive/driving-it-home/canadian-auto-workers-union-singing-off-key-as-jobs-go-south/article4105411/ | archive-url = https://archive.is/20130411231302/http://m.theglobeandmail.com/globe-drive/driving-it-home/canadian-auto-workers-union-singing-off-key-as-jobs-go-south/article4105411/ | dead-url = yes | archive-date = April 11, 2013 | accessdate = 2013-03-19 | location = Toronto }}{{failed verification|date = July 2013}} Glen Perry, a petroleum engineer for Adira Energy, has warned that including the [[Alberta Clipper pipeline]] owned by TransCanada's competitor Enbridge, there is an extensive overcapacity of oil pipelines from Canada.{{Cite news | last = Vanderklippe | first = Nathan | title = Oil sands awash in excess pipeline capacity | newspaper = [[The Globe and Mail]] | date = April 23, 2010 | url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/energy-and-resources/oil-sands-awash-in-excess-pipeline-capacity/article1543726/ | accessdate = 2012-02-22 | location=Toronto}} After completion of the Keystone XL line, oil pipelines to the U.S. may run nearly half-empty. The expected lack of volume combined with extensive construction cost overruns has prompted several petroleum refining companies to sue TransCanada. Suncor Energy hoped to recoup significant construction-related tolls, though the U.S. Energy Regulatory Commission did not rule in their favor. According to ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'',
The refiners argue that construction overruns have raised the cost of shipping on the Canadian portion of Keystone by 145 per cent while the U.S. portion has run 92 per cent over budget. They accuse TransCanada of misleading them when they signed shipping contracts in the summer of 2007. TransCanada nearly doubled its construction estimates in October 2007, from $2.8-billion (U.S.) to $5.2-billion.{{cite news | title= Pipeline fees revolt widens | url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/pipeline-fees-revolt-widens/article1548807/ | first= Nathan | last= Vanderklippe | date= 2010-04-29 | newspaper = [[The Globe and Mail]] | accessdate=2010-08-01 | location=Toronto}}
Due to an exemption the state of Kansas gave TransCanada, the local authorities would lose $50 million public revenue from property taxes for a decade. In the United States, Democrats are concerned that Keystone XL would not provide petroleum products for domestic use, but simply facilitate getting Alberta oil sands products to American coastal [[Tidewater (marketing)|ports]] on the Gulf of Mexico for export to China and other countries.{{dead link|date=January 2015}} In January 2015, Senate Republicans blocked a vote on an amendment proposed by Senator [[Edward J. Markey]], D-Mass., which would have banned exports from the Keystone XL pipeline and required that the pipeline be built with steel from the United States.{{cite news | title= Senate rejects effort to ban Keystone pipeline exports and use U.S. steel | url= http://www.sltrib.com/home/2081763-155/story.html | date= 2015-01-20 | newspaper = [[The Salt Lake Tribune]] | accessdate=2015-11-17 | location=Salt Lake City}}{{cite news | title= Senate Republicans block amendment by Sen. Ed Markey to keep Keystone XL Pipeline oil in US for American consumers exclusively | url= http://www.masslive.com/politics/index.ssf/2015/01/sen_ed_markey.html | first= Connor| last= Berry| date= 2015-01-20 | accessdate=2015-11-17 }} Frustrated by delays in getting approval for Keystone XL (via the Gulf of Mexico), the [[Enbridge Northern Gateway Pipelines]] (via Kitimat, BC) and the expansion of the existing TransMountain line to Vancouver, Alberta has intensified exploration of two northern projects "to help the province get its oil to tidewater, making it available for export to overseas markets".{{cite news|title=Alberta exploring at least two oil pipeline projects to North|first=Yadullah |last=Hussain|date=25 April 2013|publisher=Financial Post|url=http://business.financialpost.com/2013/04/25/alberta-nwt-oil-pipeline/?__lsa=d943-8e98}} Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper, spent $9 million by May 2012 and $16.5 million by May 2013 to promote Keystone XL. Until Canadian crude oil accesses international prices like LLS or Maya crude oil by "getting to [[tidewater (marketing)|tidewater]]" (south to the U.S. Gulf ports via Keystone XL for example, west to the BC Pacific coast via the proposed Northern Gateway line to ports at Kitimat, BC or north via the northern hamlet of Tuktoyaktuk, near the Beaufort Sea), the Alberta government (and to some extent, the Canadian government) is losing from $4 – 30 billion in tax and royalty revenues as the primary product of the oil sands, [[Western Canadian Select]] (WCS), the bitumen crude oil basket, is discounted so heavily against West Texas Intermediate (WTI) while Maya crude oil, a similar product close to tidewater, is reaching peak prices.{{cite news|title=Oil differential darkens Alberta's budget|first=Nathan |last=Vanderklippe|location=Calgary, Alberta|publisher=The Globe and Mail|url=http://m.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/energy-and-resources/oil-differential-darkens-albertas-budget/article7647602/?service=mobile|date=22 January 2013}} Calgary-based Canada West Foundation warned in April 2013, that Alberta is "running up against a [pipeline capacity] wall around 2016, when we will have barrels of oil we can't move". Pipeline opponents warn of disruption of farms and ranches during construction,http://www.ilr.cornell.edu/globallaborinstitute/research/upload/GLI_Impact-of-Tar-Sands-Pipeline-Spills.pdf and point to damage to water mains and sewage lines sustained during construction of an Enbridge crude oil pipeline in Michigan.{{cite web|url=http://www.freep.com/article/20130429/NEWS06/304290056/Enbridge-damage-Utility-road-fixes-could-hit-1-million|title=Enbridge damage: Utility, road fixes could hit $1 million|work=Detroit Free Press}} A report by the Cornell University Global Labor Institute noted of the [[Kalamazoo River oil spill|2010 Enbridge Tar Oil Spill]] along the [[Kalamazoo River]] in Michigan: "The experience of Kalamazoo residents and businesses provides an insight into some of the ways a community can be affected by a tar sands pipeline spill. Pipeline spills are not just an environmental concern. Pipeline spills can also result in significant economic and employment costs, although the systematic tracking of the social, health, and economic impacts of pipeline spills is not required by law. Leaks and spills from Keystone XL and other tar sands and conventional crude pipelines could put existing jobs at risk.." ===Safety issue=== A ''USA Today'' editorial pointed out that the 2013 [[Lac-Mégantic derailment]] in Quebec, in which crude oil carried by rail cars exploded and killed 47 people,{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2013/12/14/lacmgantic_how_to_get_rid_of_a_towns_oil_stain.html|title=Lac-Mégantic: How to get rid of a town's oil stain|work=thestar.com}} highlights the safety of pipelines compared to truck or rail transport. The oil in the Lac-Mégantic rail cars came from the [[Bakken Formation]] in North Dakota, an area that would be served by the Keystone expansion.Editorial, [https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2013/07/11/quebec-train-derail-oil-keystone-pipeline-editorials-debates/2510615/ Canada train disaster bolsters pipeline case: Our view], ''USA Today'', 11 July 2013. Increased oil production in North Dakota has exceeded pipeline capacity since 2010, leading to increasing volumes of crude oil being shipped by truck or rail to refineries.U.S. EIA, [http://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.cfm?id=5870 Williston Basin crude oil production and takeaway capacity are increasing] Canadian journalist Diana Furchtgott-Roth commented: "If this oil shipment had been carried through pipelines, instead of rail, families in Lac-Mégantic would not be grieving for lost loved ones today, and oil would not be polluting Lac Mégantic and the Chaudière River."Diana Furchtgott-Roth, [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/commentary/quebec-tragedy-shows-that-pipelines-are-safest-way-to-transport-oil/article13054202/ Quebec tragedy reminds us pipelines are safest way to transport oil], ''The Globe and Mail'', 8 July 2013. A ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' article in March 2014 points out that the main reason oil producers from the North Dakota Bakken Shale region are using rail and trucks to transport oil is economics not pipeline capacity. The Bakken oil is of a higher quality than the Canadian sand oil and can be sold to east coast refinery at a premium that they would not get sending it to Gulf refineries.{{cite web|last1=Sider|first1=Alison|title=In Dakota Oil Patch, Trains Trump Pipelines|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304071004579407140444547268|website=online.wsj.com|publisher=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=June 19, 2014}} The article goes on to state that there is little support remaining among these producers for the Keystone XL. On November 6, 2015, President Obama rejected Keystone XL citing the urgency of climate change as a key reason behind his decision.{{Cite web|title = ENERGY {{!}} Keystone Pipeline's Uncertain Future by David Konisky |url = https://www.indrastra.com/2015/11/ENERGY-Keystone-Pipelines-Uncertain-Future-by-David-Konisky-0429.html|website = www.indrastra.com|accessdate = 2015-11-15}} "IndraStra Global : Analysis, On The Dot" ===Public opinion=== Public opinion polls taken by independent national polling organizations toward the beginning of the dispute showed majority support for the proposed pipeline in the US. A September 2013 poll by the Pew Center found 65% favored the project and 30% opposed. The same poll found the pipeline favored by majorities of men (69%), women (61%), Democrats (51%), Republicans (82%), independents (64%), as well as by those in every division of age, education, economic status, and geographic region. The only group identified by the Pew poll with less than majority support for the pipeline was among those Democrats who identified themselves as liberal (41% in favor versus 54% opposed).Pew Center, [http://www.people-press.org/2013/09/26/continued-support-for-keystone-xl-pipeline/ Continued Support for Keystone XL Pipeline], 26 Sept. 2013. In contrast, the same polling organization published results of a February 2017 poll showing that support for the pipeline had fallen to only 42% by the beginning of 2017, with 48% of polled respondents opposing the pipeline. The Pew Center reported a 17 percentage point drop in support since 2014, with the majority of the shift due to a sharp decline in support among Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents. At the time of the poll, only 17% of Democrats favored the pipeline. Support among Republicans had also fallen (to 76%) but by no means as steeply as among Democrats.Pew Center, [http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2017/02/21/public-divided-over-keystone-xl-dakota-pipelines-democrats-turn-decisively-against-keystone/, February 21, 2017.] The overall results of polls on the Keystone XL pipeline taken by independent national polling organizations prior to 2014 are as follows: * Gallup (March 2012): 57% government should approve, 29% government should not approve{{citation|work=Gallup Report |series=Rasmussen|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/153383/americans-favor-keystone-pipeline.aspx|title= Americans favor Keystone XL pipeline, 2011-03-22}} * Rasmussen (January 2014): 57% favor, 28% oppose (of likely voters)Rasmussen Reports, [http://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/general_politics/january_2014/56_see_keystone_xl_pipeline_as_good_for_the_economy 56% See Keystone XL Pipeline As Good for the Economy], 6 January 2014. * Pew Center (September 2013): 65% favor, 30% oppose * Washington Post-ABC News (April 2014): 65% government should approve, 22% government should not approveWashington Post-ABC Poll, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/page/2010-2019/WashingtonPost/2014/03/07/National-Politics/Polling/release_303.xml Public approves of Keystone pipeline project], 17 April 2014. * USA Today (January 2014): 56% favor, 41% opposeUSA Today, [https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/01/28/keystone-pipeline-poll/4935083/ Slight majority backs Keystone pipeline], 28 January 2014. * CBS News – Roper (May 2014): 56% favor, 28% opposeCBS News, [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/cbs-news-poll-database/ CBS News poll database], May 2014. ==Ongoing developments== ===Protests and postponements=== [[File:Keystone XL demonstration, 8-2011.jpg|thumb|Demonstration against the Keystone XL extension, [[White House]], August 2011.]] In 2011, environmental and [[global warming]] activist [[Bill McKibben]] took the question of the pipeline to NASA scientist [[James Hansen]], who told McKibben the pipeline would be "game over for the planet".{{cite web | url=http://www.countercurrents.org/ross050112.htm | title="Game Over" For Planet If XL Oil Pipeline Is Built | publisher=countercurrents.org | date=2012-01-05| accessdate=2012-01-10 | author=Ross, Sherwood}} McKibben and other activists organized opposition, which coalesced in August 2011 with over 1000 nonviolent arrests at the [[White House]], which included environmental leaders such as [[Phil Radford]] and celebrities including [[Daryl Hannah]].{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/philip-radford/obama-tar-sands-keystone-pipeline_b_940617.html|title=Shining Light on Obama's Tar Sands Pipeline Decision|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=2011-08-29|first1=Philip|last1=Radford|first2=Daryl|last2=Hannah}} They promised to continue to challenge President Obama to stand by his 2008 call to "be the generation that finally frees America from the tyranny of oil" as he entered the 2012 reelection campaign. A relatively broad coalition came together, including the Republican governor [[Dave Heineman]] and senators [[Ben Nelson]] and [[Mike Johanns]] from Nebraska, and some Democratic funders such as [[Susie Tompkins Buell]].{{cite news |url= http://www.newyorker.com/talk/comment/2011/11/28/111128taco_talk_mayer#ixzz1eftWuSRW |title= Taking It to the Streets |first = Jane |last = Mayer |newspaper=[[The New Yorker]] |date=2011-11-28 |accessdate=2011-12-01}} On November 6, 2011, several thousand environmentalist supporters, some shouldering a long black inflatable replica of a pipeline, formed a human chain around the White House to convince Barack Obama to block the controversial Keystone XL project. Organizer Bill McKibben said, "this has become not only the biggest environmental flash point in many, many years, but maybe the issue in recent times in the Obama administration when he's been most directly confronted by people in the street. In this case, people willing, hopeful, almost dying for him to be the Barack Obama of 2008."{{Cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/nov/09/keystone-xl-pipeline-obama-reelection | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Amy | last=Goodman | title=Keystone: pipeline to Obama's re-election | date=2011-11-09}} On October 4, 2012, actress and activist [[Daryl Hannah]] and 78-year-old Texas landowner Eleanor Fairchild were arrested for criminal [[trespassing]] and other charges after they were accused of standing in front of pipeline construction equipment on Fairchild's farm in [[Winnsboro, Texas|Winnsboro]], a town about {{convert|100|mi}} east of Dallas.{{cite news|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/nation/15598994-418/daryl-hannah-freed-following-arrest-in-pipeline-protest.html |title=Daryl Hannah freed following arrest in pipeline protest |newspaper=Chicago Sun-Times |date=October 6, 2012}} Fairchild has owned the land since 1983 and refused to sign any agreements with TransCanada. Her land was seized by [[eminent domain]]. On October 31, 2012, [[Green Party of the United States|Green Party]] presidential candidate [[Jill Stein]] was also arrested in Texas for criminal trespass after trying to deliver food and supplies to the Keystone XL protesters.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-10-31/news/sns-rt-us-usa-politics-greenpartybre89u1ti-20121031_1_pipeline-protest-keystone-xl-jill-stein|title=Green Party presidential hopeful arrested in pipeline protest|author=James B. Kelleher|work=Chicago Tribune|date=31 October 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/green-party-candidate-jill-stein-arrested/2012/10/31/0f309970-2373-11e2-8448-81b1ce7d6978_story.html|title=Green Party presidential candidate Jill Stein charged with trespassing in Keystone XL protest|first=Steven|last=Mufson|work=Washington Post|date=31 October 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}} [[File:13feb17 nokxl dc.jpg|thumb|An estimated crowd of 35,000–50,000 gathers near the Washington Monument on February 17, 2013 to protest the Keystone XL pipeline and support action on climate change.]] On February 17, 2013, approximately 35,000 to 50,000 protestors attended a rally in Washington, D.C. organized by [[Sierra Club|The Sierra Club]], [[350.org]], and [[Hip Hop Caucus|The Hip Hop Caucus]], in what Bill McKibben described as "the biggest climate rally by far, by far, by far, in U.S. history".{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/feb/17/keystone-xl-pipeline-protest-dc | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Suzanne | last=Goldenberg | title=Keystone XL protesters pressure Obama on climate change promise | date=2013-02-17}}{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/02/thousands-rally-in-washington-to-protest-keystone-pipeline-87745.html#ixzz2LDwj7Myp|title=Thousands rally in Washington to protest Keystone pipeline|author=Talia Buford|work=POLITICO}} The event featured [[Lennox Yearwood]]; Chief Jacqueline Thomas, immediate past chief of the [[Saik'uz First Nation]]; [[Van Jones]]; Crystal Lameman, of [[Beaver Lake Cree Nation]]; [[Michael Brune]], [[Sheldon Whitehouse|Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse (D-RI)]], and others as invited speakers.{{cite news|last1=Graybeal|first1=Susan|title=40,000 People Reported at Climate Change Rally|url=https://news.yahoo.com/40-000-people-reported-climate-change-rally-190900613.html|accessdate=July 26, 2014|work=Yahoo News|date=February 18, 2013}} Simultaneous 'solidarity' protests were also organized in several other cities across the United States, Europe, and Canada.{{Cite news|url=https://insideclimatenews.org/news/20130217/keystone-xl-oil-sands-tar-sands-pipeline-canada-activists-350.org-sierra-club-protest-march-climate-change|title=Biggest Environmental Rally in Decades Attracts Nationwide Media Attention|date=2013-02-18|work=InsideClimate News|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en}} Protesters called on President Obama to reject the planned pipeline extension when deciding the fate of the pipeline after [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[John Kerry]] completes a review of the project.{{cite web |last=Rafferty |first=Andrew |title=Thousands rally in D.C. against Keystone Pipeline |url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/17/16996283-thousands-rally-in-dc-against-keystone-pipeline |publisher=[[NBC News]] |accessdate=21 February 2013}} "[B]ecause of broader market dynamics and options for crude oil transport in the North American logistics system, the upstream and downstream activities are unlikely to be substantially different whether or not the proposed Project is constructed."{{citation|title=Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement (SEIS) ''Ch. 2.2.3 No Action Alternative''|url=http://keystonepipeline-xl.state.gov/finalseis/index.htm|date=January 2014|work=Department of State|accessdate=2 February 2014}} On March 2, 2014, approximately 1000–1200 protesters marched from Georgetown University to the White House to stage a protest against the Keystone Pipeline. 398 arrests were made of people tying themselves to the White House fence with zip-ties and lying on a black tarp in front of the fence. The tarp represented an oil spill, and many protesters dressed in white jumpsuits covered in black ink, symbolizing oil-covered HazMat suits, laid down upon the tarp. ===Alternative projects=== On November 16, 2011, [[Enbridge]] announced it was buying ConocoPhillips' 50% interest in the [[Seaway pipeline]] that flowed from the Gulf of Mexico to the Cushing hub. In cooperation with [[Enterprise Products|Enterprise Products Partners LP]] it is reversing the Seaway pipeline so that an oversupply of oil at Cushing can reach the Gulf.{{cite news | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-11-16/conocophillips-sells-seaway-colonial-stakes-for-2-billion.html | title = Enbridge Plans to Reverse Pipe Between Cushing and Houston | first1 = Mike | last1 = Lee | first2 = Edward | last2 = Klump | agency = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 2011-11-16 | accessdate = 2011-11-26}} This project replaced the earlier proposed alternative Wrangler pipeline project from Cushing to the Gulf Coast.{{cite news | url = http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-09-29/enterprise-enbridge-propose-keystone-pipeline-alternative.html | title = Enterprise, Enbridge Propose Keystone Pipeline Alternative | first1 = Mike | last1 = Lee | first2 = Bradley | last2 = Olson | work = [[Bloomberg Businessweek]] | agency = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = 2012-05-19 | accessdate = 2011-11-26 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111231082801/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-09-29/enterprise-enbridge-propose-keystone-pipeline-alternative.html | archivedate = 2011-12-31 | df = }} It began reversed operations on May 17, 2012.{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/19/us-oil-seaway-startup-idUSBRE84I0EC20120519 | title = Seaway pipeline sends oil to Texas in historic reversal | first1 = Bruce | last1 = Nichols | agency = [[Rueters]] | date = 2011-09-29 | accessdate = 2012-07-27 | work=Reuters}} However, according to industries, the Seaway line alone is not enough for oil transportation to the Gulf Coast.{{cite news | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203699404577046270455388032 | title = More Pipelines Needed to Follow Seaway's Path | first1 = Ben| last1 = Lefebvre | newspaper = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | date = 2011-11-18 | accessdate = 2011-11-26 | id = {{required subscription}}}} On January 19, 2012, TransCanada announced it may shorten the initial path to remove the need for federal approval.{{Cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-01-19/transcanada-may-shorten-keystone-xl-bypass-federal-review.html | work=Bloomberg | title=Keystone pipeline: TransCanada to Shorten Route and Bypass Federal Review | date=2012-01-19}} TransCanada said that work on that section of the pipeline could start in June 2012{{Cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-03-22/obama-s-speedy-keystone-review-won-t-accelerate-cushing-pipeline.html | work=Bloomberg | first1=Bradley | last1=Olson | first2=Mike | last2=Lee | title=Obama's Speedy Keystone Review Won't Accelerate Cushing Pipe | date=2012-03-22}} and be on-line by the middle to late 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.transcanada.com/gulf-coast-pipeline-project.html|title=Page Not Found|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130121135703/http://transcanada.com/gulf-coast-pipeline-project.html|archivedate=2013-01-21|df=}} In April 2013, it was learned that the government of Alberta was investigating, as an alternative to the pipeline south through the United States, a shorter all-Canadian pipeline north to the Arctic coast, from where the oil would be taken by tanker ships through the [[Arctic Ocean]] to markets in Asia and EuropeJill Burke, [http://alaskadispatch.com/article/20130425/alaska-watches-canadians-consider-shipping-tar-sands-oil-across-arctic-ocean Alaska watches Canadians consider shipping tar sands oil across Arctic Ocean], Alaska Dispatch, 30 April 2013 and in August, TransCanada announced a new proposal to create a longer all-Canada pipeline, called [[Energy East pipeline|Energy East]], that would extend as far east as the port city of [[Saint John, New Brunswick]], at the same time providing feedstock to refineries in Montreal, Quebec City and Saint John.TransCanada, [http://www.transcanada.com/news-releases-article.html?id=1746092 Energy East News Release], August 1, 2013 The Enbridge "Alberta Clipper" expansion of the existing cross-border Line 67 pipeline has been continuing since late 2013. When completed it will add 350,000 bpd new capacity to the existing pipeline for cumulative total of 800,000 bpd.{{cite web|url=http://www.enbridge.com/MainlineEnhancementProgram/Canada/Alberta-Clipper-Capacity-Expansion-Phase-II.aspx|title=Enbridge website|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140225235133/http://www.enbridge.com/MainlineEnhancementProgram/Canada/Alberta-Clipper-Capacity-Expansion-Phase-II.aspx|archivedate=2014-02-25|df=}} In late 2014 Enbridge announced it is awaiting final approval from the US State Department and expects to proceed with the last phase in mid-2015.{{Cite news|url = https://online.wsj.com/articles/enbridge-sees-one-year-delay-in-u-s-approval-for-cross-border-oil-pipeline-1412113119|title = Enbridge Sees One-Year Delay in U.S. Approval for Cross-Border Oil Pipeline|last = Dawson|first = Chester|date = September 30, 2014|work = Wall Street Journal|accessdate = November 19, 2014}} ===Lawsuits=== In September 2009, independent refiner CVR sued TransCanada for Keystone Pipeline tolls seeking $250 million damage compensation or release from transportation agreements. CVR alleged that the final tolls for the Canadian segment of the pipeline were 146% higher than initially presented, while the tolls for the U.S. segment were 92% higher.{{cite news | title= Independent refiner CVR sues TransCanada's Keystone Pipeline | url= http://www.allbusiness.com/transportation/pipeline-transportation-oil-gas/13114806-1.html | date= 2009-09-18 | work = The Oil Daily | first = Barbara | last = Shook | publisher= AllBusiness.com, Inc | accessdate= 2010-08-01}} In April 2010, three smaller refineries sued TransCanada to break Keystone transportation contracts, saying the new pipeline has been beset with cost overruns. In October 2009, a suit was filed by the [[Natural Resources Defense Council]] that challenged the pipeline on the grounds that its permit was based on a deficient environmental impact statement. The suit was thrown out by a federal judge on procedural grounds, ruling that the NRDC lacked the authority to bring it.{{cite news | title= NRDC's Suit to Block Canada-US Oil Pipeline Thrown Out | url= http://www.heatingoil.com/blog/nrdcs-suit-to-block-canada-us-oil-pipeline-thrown-out102/ | date= 2009-10-02 | agency= [[Associated Press]] | accessdate= 2010-07-22 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418200508/http://www.heatingoil.com/blog/nrdcs-suit-to-block-canada-us-oil-pipeline-thrown-out102/ | archivedate= 2010-04-18 | df= }} In June 2012, [[Sierra Club]], Inc., Clean Energy Future Oklahoma, and the East Texas Sub Regional Planning Commission filed a joint complaint in the [[United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma]] seeking injunctive relief and petitioning for a review of the [[U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]]' action in issuing Nationwide Permit 12 permits for the Cushing, Oklahoma, to the Gulf Coast portion of the pipeline. The suit alleges that, contrary to the federal [[Administrative Procedure Act (United States)|Administrative Procedure Act]], 5 U.S.C. § 701 et. seq., the Corps' issuance of the permits was arbitrary and capricious and an abuse of discretion.{{cite news | title=Enviros Sue to Stop Keystone Pipeline Project | url= http://www.cnsenvironmentallaw.com/2012/07/03/1014.htm | agency = Courthouse News Service |accessdate= 2012-07-18}} In early January 2016, TransCanada announced it would initiate an [[ISDS]] claim under [[NAFTA]] against the United States, seeking $15 billion in damages and calling the denial of a permit for Keystone XL "arbitrary and unjustified."[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/energy-and-resources/transcanada-files-lawsuit-over-keystone-pipeline-rejection/article28038526/ TransCanada to launch NAFTA claim over Keystone rejection], The Globe and Mail, January 6, 2016 ==See also== {{Portal|Energy|Infrastructure}} * [[List of oil pipelines]] * [[List of oil refineries]] * [[List of articles
